You place your palm on the rough bark, feeling its warmth with your skin, and you appear to sense the immobile tree living and breathing nevertheless.
You think of how the tree is the source of life and how it nurtures and supports it, and then provides you with the bed that will take you on your last sea voyage…

You loosen your fingers in order to get a better grip on the branches, but there's a sudden complication — a narrow cleft in the bark won't let your fingers go. You pull and twist your hand until your fingers are released, red and swollen.
You reach out your hand to take a branch, but it stings your fingers maliciously. A twig that looks like a long thorn has ripped your skin open rather nastily.
You touch the bark and think of how rough and solid it is — a far cry from the soft human skin. You think to yourself, "It figures — a tree has no shelter from rain or frost."
You pry up the bark, and a large sheet peels off, which you receive gladly. A great piece!

You try to hack off a sizable piece of the tree's skin, but it feels as though it were armored. You make too hard an effort and cut your finger, and now you have to spend some time to take care of the wound and stop the bleeding.

You see the grooves in the bark form a complex wavy pattern and try to take a closer look at them. You are surprised — you see clear knife marks. What was whoever had left them trying to write? Their name? Or a plea for help? Could it be a warning of some sort of danger?

You remember how your mother used to collect bark from young branches. She was a skilled healer and used her brews and infusions to treat everyone's ailments, be it burns, joint aches, or sprained tendons.
You look at the tree and think about the unbreakable link between the bitter smell of the bark, its brownish-gray color and dry crackly texture, and the roughness you feel when you touch it.

You are completely engrossed in your work and it takes you a while to realize just what it was that had just fallen on your head with so much noise. You jump aside, startled, and rub your hurting head. There is a large club-like branch on the ground. The tree spirit probably doesn't like your company.

Your industriousness is punished by the tree — it throws a small twig right into your eye. You leap aside and blink furiously. The bark is the least of your worries now — all you want is to get the twig out of your eye, which looks like a waterfall of tears.
The bark peels off, and a cloud of dust appears in the space underneath. It reaches your nostrils, and you sneeze thunderously.
You think that it's best to peel bark right after the rain, when it soaks up some water and peels from the body of the tree easily.
You slap the tree trunk — you have a feeling that its bark will be perfect for making bowls and mugs.

You peel off the bark thinking that the best kind of kindling you can get is the bark of a birch tree. Should even that fail to start a fire, you have a special trick: the pieces of birch bark need to form a triangular mound.
You think that you can fashion a mug out of the bark — simple, yet elegant in its own way: of a deep yellow hue, just like butter. Or the sun during the last third of the day.
You think that bark requires special treatment, unless you intend to use it for kindling — you must oil it to keep it supple. Or soak it in water, at the very least.

You look at the rough patterns on the bark and remember how there'd be boxes and lidded baskets made of birch in every household back home. Those were wrought very finely — there were patterned belts along the top and the bottom.

You study the piece of bark and think that the only thing you can make is a mug of the simplest sort. But your land sure had skilled craftsmen — they could even make containers you could use to boil water, no less! And just to think of the decorations — all those painted, cut-out, and filed-out ornaments.
You muse that you have never seen any larches on the island. Those are best for all kinds of containers and utensils — the wood doesn't crack or split.

You think that with some trees you can only use the bark for making containers. The birch bark, for instance, can be used for almost anything — you can use it to make a bowl, if that's what you need, or, say, a ladle!

You feel the bark and think the rumor you heard about the nomads that had roamed along the southern borders of the Empire until recently — apparently, they have this custom of covering all their bark vessels with thick layers of butter or cream. Fancy wasting food on that! You can do without it perfectly well.
You focus your eyes on the roots — it seems as though you can see something unusual among them. You were right! With a cry of joy, you pocket your extileent find!
As you estimate the amount of work required, you pick a piece of sticky resin up with your fingernail and pop it into your mouth. It's more fun to work when your jaws have something to do.

You look at a gray toad that has crawled out onto one of the roots. You pry it up with your foot and you toss it aside — its pimply skin looks revolting. You wonder whether there is any truth to the rumor that you can find a gemstone inside a toad's head.
Sweat is pouring into your eyes. You stop to rub it off with your hand.
You turn your palms upwards and cringe as you blow on them. They're all covered in blisters and cracks, and they won't let you get much work done.
You think of tree roots reaching so far underground that no human can ever reach. Maybe the water they drink comes from the very source of wisdom.

You suddenly see an old mark on the bark that has already healed. You wonder who could have marked their way here in such a manner. Someone from mainland, perhaps? Or the natives? A chill runs down your spine.
You pretend to be a mighty warrior battling with a giant monster. Your sword pierces the wooden flesh, chopping off tentacles. Severed limbs convulse, and the monster dies right at your feet.
You are concerned about the wind — it might be too strong. If the wind joins forces with the tree, they can play an evil trick on you by squashing you like a bug when you least expect it.
You examine the trunk to find out just where to start chopping. If the tree is bent or crooked, it's much easier.
You don't mess around with trees — when something that big falls on someone, he'll be squashed like a grape!
You mark the place of the first cut. Once the cut is made, you take it out just like a slice of a pie, and then you fell the tree in that direction.
You think that it's hard to do this without a helper. You could obviously use some assistance in pulling the rope and pushing the trunk.
You cut the branches from the side the tree will fall onto — it will weigh less, and you will be safe from flying wood chips.
It would, of course, be easier to climb the tree and then start felling it from the top. But there's a saying that you shouldn't cut the branch you're sitting on.
You try to remember when it last rained. A moist tree is heavy, and its trunk is slippery. It will be much harder in that case.
You put your hand on the rough bark and ask the spirits of the forest and the earth to forgive you for taking away one of their kin.
Now isn't that a pretty stump! You could put some dinnerware on and sit down to eat right away. Just like a table, I swear!
Uprooting stumps is hard — worse than any forced labor. First you need to dig a trench around it, and then you must cut off the roots. You'll know the true meaning of "weary" by the time it is over!

You have dug a trench around the stump, but it's still rooted solidly in the earth. You sit down on it to catch a breather. It would be more convenient to pry it up with a stick, and then to use it like a lever. It would probably fly up like a stone from a slingshot.
You bend down over the cutting and inhale the very essence of the forest with your nostrils. It smells of wood, moss, and fungal rot.
You trace the rough texture of the cut with your finger, studying the sequence of rings — dark and light, wide and narrow, admiring the great age of the felled tree.

You look at the stump and it looks to you just like a giant octopulos with its tentacles deep underground, holding tightly onto a treasure chest and absolutely refusing to let go. No matter how deep you dig or how fiercely you chop.
You feel reluctant to strain your back by uprooting the stump. You think that, perhaps, you should burn it.
You rub your lower back — the last thing you need is to rupture your back and spend weeks convalescing.
What an enormous tree it was! Not even two people together could get their arms around the trunk!
Come on already, open that tentacle grip of yours! See how hard it holds on! It must be sucking the blood of Mother Earth. But they won't do you much good now that your head's been cut off!
The wood shavings fly merrily in every direction — it is as though small beetles disturbed by the saw were leaving their dwelling.

Toward you and then away, toward you — and away. The monotony of these repetitive actions is making you melancholy. It looks like the ritual dance of those wild steppe tribes when they try to make it rain.
You examine the log from both sides. What if you approach from the other end? It seems as though it might be easier this way.

You pull the saw toward yourself and rub your palm on the log. It feels as if it were licked by a dragon's rough tongue of stone. You take a good look at your hand and see that the skin is raw and bleeding.

The saw makes a singing sound and jumps away from the log. You try to get it started once again, but it bends and jumps away once more. You quickly mumble a prayer to guard yourself against the trickery of evil spirits and get back to work.

You feel a sudden sting. You bring your hand closer to your eyes to take a closer look and see a splinter in your palm. Although this is no mere splinter — it looks more like a large chip of wood driven about half an inch deep into your palm.
The saw mark on the log reminds you of a grin. You tell the tree that it is free to mock all it wants. We'll see who gets to laugh in the end!
A single awkward movement makes you stop. You kick the log angrily — its hard fibers have bent the saw, and you will now have to waste your precious time on fixing it.
You feel the log thinking of how dry wood is harder than wet wood. However, even though it is easier to saw a wet log, the wet sawdust clings to the saw and steals away its power and speed.
The harsh and vibrating sound made by the saw cuts through the silence, rings in your ears, and scares away the birds that sat nearby.
You've had bad luck with the log. It is hard and crooked, and the saw sinks in it as though the wood were a swamp.

You realize you had approached this task wrong from the very start, and now the handle of the saw has rubbed your hand raw. You look for something to use as a bandage lest you leave all your skin on the handle.

You recall old men mentioning a special tree whose roots go all the way down to a holy sanctum deep underground. The tree was supposed to bear fruit that would give anyone who ate it the knowledge of many hidden things. You cut your daydream short by reminding yourself that you cannot fell that tree with a simple axe or an ordinary saw…

You place your palm on the rough surface of the tree and remember that all trees drink juices from underground, which means god himself imbues them with strength. You whisper your thanks to the god for his permission to take one of his trees.
You remember what your father would say about labor of any sort: "Eyes may fear, but the hands will still steer." He was right, of course — all things are difficult before they are easy.
You remember your father, who would always say: "A man's strength is in his work." You shouldn't idle about while there's still work to be done.
You like the smell of resin that comes from the tree. You pry a piece of opaque resin from the bark and pop it into your mouth. It has a pleasant woody taste with strong pine-needle notes.
You dig a shallow pit for the little tree — this way, the roots will find air quicker. You cannot help comparing the pit to a cozy little house.
You have planted the sapling, and are now tilling the soil around it — it will be more comfortable and easier for the young roots to breathe this way.
You take a look at your little tree and remove the broken branches, weak and helpless. They will not revive, at any rate, but they will take away some of the plant's vital juices.
You think of manure and how nice it would be to mix some with the soil to keep the roots warm and well-nourished.

You choose a small hillock to plant your sapling. Your grandfather already knew this, and he passed the knowledge on to you: the soil on such mounds is more nutritious; there's also more air, and a smaller chance that excess moisture will cause root rot.
You examine the little tree — it knows where it wants to grow. The darker side has to face the south, and the lighter side will face the darker side of the sky.
You plant the sapling and stomp around to make sure the ground is compact. Now you can take a breather.
You utter a short prayer for the God of the Netherworld, who watches over everything that happens underground, would make the roots grow better and give vigor to the trunk.
You examine your tree and gently remove the leaves, taking care not to damage the burgeons. The sapling doesn't need them yet, and all they do is squander water.

You plant the sapling and are now looking at your hand — there is a piece of bark deep under one of your fingernails. The finger hurts and you're trying to pry the splinter loose, but to no avail. You think that if you stick about a hundred such splinters under someone's fingernails, that will amount to proper torture.
You have tried to choose sturdy trees for planting. After all, a rotten root bears no sweet fruit.
Before you plant the sapling, you carefully slice a piece of one of its side roots. You look at the clear white cut with pleasure — the root is alive and healthy. A dry root would have been brown.

You touch the little trunk with your hand and think that trees have real healing power. Healers know which trees cure ailments, which fill one's body with strength, and which make sure the head thinks pleasant thoughts.

They say there's a tree that is a thousand times stronger than these — wider and taller. But has anyone seen it? It is said to be guarded by wild beasts who tear apart anyone who dares to approach. But if there are no living witnesses, who can testify to the tree's existence?
You make a vow: if the tree lives, you will bury its first fruit in the ground to express your gratitude to God.
You want to cover the roots with soil, but suddenly notice something in the pit. You reach for it and pick up a strange object.
You recall your father's special method of planting trees. He would plant them in such a way that they would protect the house from the wind, as well as summer heat.
You run your hand over the grass and cringe — a sharp blade of grass that looks like a double-edge sword has cut your palm.
You see something that doesn't look like either a rock or a pile of leaves in the grass. You bend down and pick up a very interesting item.

You make a heavy step and notice that you've stepped on a serpent's tail when it's already too late. The reptile is long enough to bend over backwards and drive a venomous tooth into your leg. You crush the snake's head with your other foot, but what you need to do first and foremost is remove the poison from your body.

You pick up a pale pink flower and crush the petals in your fingers. A pleasant tangy smell reaches your nostril. You think it would be nice to gather some of them and use them to brew a bracing beverage that's very good for you.
You see fragrant white flowers in the grass. You aren't tempted by the smell — you know that if you spend a few minutes near them, you'll get a headache.
You take a deep breath. You breathe in a special kind of air that smells of wet earth and fresh grass, with a slight aroma of flowers.

You touch the serrated leaves and remember that this plant's flowers can only be seen once a year, so who has ever seen them? This flower can float in the air and lead you to buried treasure. That's why it doesn't reveal itself to just anyone.
You bend down to see whether the mushroom is maggoty. You recall the words of your mother about every mushroom being edible. All you need to know is how to cook it right.

You draw the leaves apart and your hand touches a bush that's all covered in thorns. One of the thorns pricks your finger, and you suck out a droplet of blood — you never know whether or not the bush might be poisonous.
You look deep into the grass, trying to find yellow berries. They are watery and rather bland, but they remind you of home.
You saw an unusual plant. Its jagged leaves resemble flames of fire. Or the ornaments on the attire of the northerners.

You see a strange plant — its leaves are rolled into narrow tubes, and the flowers have shiny white petals. You break off the stalk — maybe you'll get a chance to show it to someone who knows what this plant is and what properties it has.

You pick up a branch and start waving it around as though it were a sword. You strike left and right, scattering the flowers, which fall on the ground. You shake your "sword" victoriously, and then you shake your head — such juvenile behavior.

An unpleasant smell reaches your nostrils, and your experienced eye notices off-white bell-like flowers amidst the grass. You recognize these flowers — their juice makes cow milk taste revolting. Should a cow be stupid enough to eat a lot of them, it will behave like mad, and may even gore its owner with its horns.

You see the plant you need, but you refrain from picking it. Its leaves are rolled into tubes, with white cobwebs all over. The caterpillars have managed to beat you to it, and now the plant is only edible to the insect folk.

You are amazed by the sheer variety of grasses. There are hundreds of hues and smells, and they are making your head spin. You stop. Then you realize that your head is spinning because of the vapors of jimsonweed, and that you need some fresh air to chase them away.
You draw the grass apart and jerk your hand back — it feels as if you touched a flame. You see how the poisonous sap is making your hand burn, redden, and get covered in small blisters.
The hundreds and hundreds of grasses underneath your feet exude an unbelievable smell. You tear off the head of a flower and chew it slowly, feeling the taste of honey on your tongue.
You pick the herb you need, only to notice the plant is dry, with withered leaves and a brittle stalk. You crush it in your hands and scatter the fragments to the wind.

An unassuming bug jumps onto your hand. You thoughtlessly flick it away, and the strong odor informs you that you have just chased away a shield bug. Its acrid stench will now accompany you halfway to your destination at least.

You bend down to break away a stalk at the very base, but a tiny striped warrior attacks you. You recognize it as a wasp, and angrily rub the sting. Your hand itches and swells up in an ugly red patch.

You watch out for the stalks and leaves, but you also keep in mind the roots, which you dig out. You hope to find the Root of Life — it grows from the very depths of the Earth, and the Great God himself is said to give it power.

You try to wave away a pesky fly that keeps getting into your face, and accidentally touch the grass, whose sharp tongues grow tall, facing the sky. The long green blade slices your finger open like any knife.
You pick a leaf of grass and pop the narrow edge into your mouth. You crush the narrow stalk with your teeth, sucking out the sweet sap.
You see a handful of red berries right next to the ground. They may not be very juicy, but they're very sweet. This is typical for open places in the sun, as you note.

You draw the green grass apart and see a large beetle with an ugly horn on its snout. You think that the monster is watching you, and has even lowered its head menacingly. You spit angrily and let the grass spring back to cover up the beetle. You are not afraid — far from it — but what if it's an evil spirit guarding its territory.
You look under your feet, and your heart fills with joy — you have found a rare ingredient!

Your hand reaches for the ripe grapes as though it were moving of its own accord. You swallow one grape after another, but, before you even finish the last one, you feel your face and hands begin to itch. You suddenly feel a chill inside — someone must have cursed you!
You stop to take a deep breath. The smell of the herbs and the flowers makes you dizzy and fills your soul with joy at the same time. You could praise all the gods right now.

You think that someday you will find your recipe for immortality. You have thought out the recipe of the potion in great detail, but there is still something missing — doubtlessly, some small and very rare herb…

You think that you are really close to your own recipe for transforming rocks into gold. You were almost lucky once, and the rock even took on a yellow hue, but the magic vanished in the light of day. However, you're not a quitter and hope to fill your purse with gold ingots of your own someday.
You sort through the herbs and notice that your hands are green and emit a pleasant herbal smell.
You think irritatedly that your fingers have grown completely rough from all the work, and it's really hard for you to pick thin stalks and the heads of small flowers.

You recall having invented the potion of youth a long time ago, when you were still a lad — you even managed to test it on your old nanny. She complained the drink did her no good, and even had to spend the whole night sitting in the bushes. But you saw how her face, which had looked like a baked turnip, became really smooth by the morning. She claims the accursed drink made her face swell up, but you know the truth.
You feel the stalks, but they're not supple enough and rather dry — they won't be useful to you.
You raise your face to the trees — sometimes they are all covered in sturdy green ropes. These parasitic vines are just what you need — as good as any rope.
You try to estimate whether the stalks you have found are strong enough by stretching them hard. You nod approvingly — these should do.

You remember how one of your uncles, who wasn't particularly fond of work, made one of his tools out of an old root. So what happened next? Obviously enough, they wore out quickly, and the stone fell out. The uncle lost his axe as well as one of his toes.
You casually pick a red berry from a bush and toss it in your mouth. Sweeter than honey!

You are going through the types of knots you know in your mind, thinking of which of them would be best to use on the threads. The woman's knot isn't called this for nothing — it is only fit for tying head-scarves. A weaver's knot or a cow's knot will hold much better.

You notice a suitable stalk and grab it deftly. But it proves harder than you thought — it holds fast, and you need some effort. The tough old stalk breaks with a loud crack, and you fly like a missile from the catapult, landing on your back and raising a cloud of dust from the grass. You get up groaning and rubbing your aching back.
You think that hemp fiber is the best material for a rope. Hair is good, too, likewise woven tendons.

You think that you have finally found a fitting material, but notice a spider's web nearby. You pick up the cobweb and use it to wipe your hands — it has been known since times immemorial that a spider's thread makes one's hands strong and agile.
You bend down and notice that the grass and the rocks aren't the only things you see under your feet. You think you have found something quite extraordinary.

Your long stride is broken by a root protruding from the ground. You flutter your hands as if you were trying to get airborne, but the miracle does not happen. You fall down like a heavy sack. Now you know what it really means to knock the breath out of someone.

One of your earliest childhood memories is of ships entering the harbor, well-cured by the wind and the sea. Swarthy tanned sailors hoist down all sorts of goods — sometimes the children gawking from underneath get their hands on something, too. An overripe exotic fruit, a darkened piece of wood, or an extremely strong piece of rope from the rigging.
You pull on the threads, but they're taut as hard as a bowstring and cut your palm with ease. You clench your fist and see a trickle of blood come out.

You recollect how they used to weave rope in the days of your — the plants were dried, soaked, and then broken and scutched by the women. Then they would heckle and card it, and only after than they could start weaving a rope.

You think some nettle would come in handy — you can use it to make strong and durable rope. All you need to do is find tall plants. Then you have to remove the leaves and make a cut lengthwise — not too deep, but not too shallow, either.
You think that if you fail to find a suitable material, bark will do, too. If you slice it up in long thin strips, it is also usable.

You remember how your mother's agile fingers would expertly crush dried threads, spin them, twist them, and pull them between the thumb and the back of a knife. It's common knowledge — the cleaner the threads, the stronger the rope.
You think that you could make a fitting rope if you came across some hemp. All you need to do is to choose a female plant. Male plants are more suitable for making fabric.
You try to choose a vigorous plant with a thick stalk — it will probably bear replanting easier.
You say the magic words to make the spirits of the forest take heed of you. You cannot so much as pick a flower or crush a blade of grass without their leave.
You keep searching, but you fail to notice a tree's sharp claw reaching for you. Your face gets covered in scratches in an instant. Yet you are happy that you have managed to protect your eyes.
Wow! What could this be? You bend down and pick up something one doesn't usually find in the forest.

You think that with gardening you never can tell what the result will be. Maybe you just shouldn't bother… Then you recall your mother's succulent apple pies, or her rhubarb pie… Ah well, pies are worth the effort.
You are thinking of the Goddess of Fertility, whom you have to placate — nothing grows without her leave, not even the nettles by the side of the road.
You rub your neck. Staring into the ground all the time is strenuous — even a neck of steel would break eventually.

You see a beetle lying helpless on its back. "What a clumsy creature!" you think as you poke the beetle with a stick. Once the beetle gets hopeful and grabs onto it with its feet, you flick it down to the ground. The beetle is on the ground again, trying hard to open its wings. You laugh out loud — that was a funny joke.

You hear a deafening crackle and stop in your tracks. Cold sweat runs down your back. What could it be?! A bear… or a boar? Or the spirits of the forest coming to get you? One of the natives with a poisoned spear hiding in the bushes? All is silent… You realize the crack came from the twig you have stepped on.
You see a fitting plant and pull it by the stalk instead of digging it out. That wasn't a good idea! The rough stalk scrapes the palms of your hands raw.
You notice some horsetail. It's an extremely verminous plant — you cannot drive it out or pull it out. But it may not be as useless as people think… They say horsetails guard gold.
You are thinking of digging up some of those bushes with pumpkin-colored flowers — an infusion of those makes wounds heal much faster. And the small magenta ones are good against cough.
You think that all the plants get their juices from the Earth. And Mother Earth must be getting her power from the Dreamer who sleeps within her.
Once I finish planting, I'll read a prayer in every corner and bury some charmed plants her to make sure those voracious beetles leave the green leaves well alone.
You are concerned about moles — those pests can dig up the plants' roots, suffocating them.

You remember how back home you had to call the priests, and they would determine whether or not you could plant anything. They should know better — after all, they ask permission from the gods for everything.
You have failed to notice old yellow nettles. They sting your hand, even though they have already withered. The older a nettle, the sharper its teeth.

You see a plant with unfamiliar jagged leaves and large red berries. This plant doesn't resemble any of those known to you. You break off a branch to dry it and show it to a knowledgeable person whenever you get the chance.
You see some crimson berries hiding among the leaves. You hastily toss them into your mouth — their juice quenches thirst perfectly.
You feel something sting your ankle painfully. As you thought — you didn't give the reptile the right-of-way, and it retaliated immediately.
You draw the tree branches apart in search of cocoons and think of the amazing talent of the caterpillars — to create sliding threads that are nearly weightless.

You examine the branches in hopes of finding a cocoon, thinking the fabric that glistens in the sun does not necessarily have to be worn by kings. These days every peasant can dress in glorious silk — all you need to know is how to unravel the caterpillars' cocoons.

You cannot yet claim a good yield of silkworm cocoons, but you already imagine how you will dunk them in boiling water and then start unraveling the softened cocoons. Thin, near-invisible threads will stay on your fingers.

You look at the branches and wonder who may have thought of taking threads from caterpillars first. Darned if you know! The old emperor is said to have bought the secret for a few chests of gold! Or, perhaps, the nomads from the south were the first to have thought of it.
You take a look at the tree, thinking that butterflies born in palaces of silk are rather unsightly — grayish wings, rather dull, looking like a large moth.

You think that the butterfly that you noticed in front of you was a mulberry silkmoth. You are trying to see where it is headed in case you see some cocoons. You would like to catch it and find out whether it's true that butterfly mouths are sealed and they never eat during their winged life.

Even though you did notice a butterfly, you keep on looking for cocoons. You know that silkmoths can breed several times during a summer, so the same tree can have butterflies, caterpillars, and cocoons on it.
You remember seeing trees with all leaves devoured by silkworms. Those caterpillars are extremely voracious, and eat leaves the way fire eats wood.

You find a tight white cocoon and are examining it. You are amazed with the diligence of these little weavers — it can take them four days to build a house of threads, tirelessly shaking their head from side to side.
You think that even in case of silkworms males work harder than females. Males make tidy and thick cocoons, whereas females tend to slack off.
You find some cocoons and place them on your palm. They are white, with a rough feel, and very light — they look like the eggs of some forest bird.
You haven't found any cocoons here, but there are lots of berries on the tree, large and fragrant. Their sweet juice fills your mouth.
You see something white on the tree and you remove it from the leaf. You see a cocoon of a regular caterpillar — utterly worthless. You crush the cocoon in your hand and a greenish liquid comes out.
You try to push the branch away, and it scratches your face with its claws. You rub your cheek with your hand — there must certainly be a red mark there.

It occurs to you that silkworms have a fine taste, what with them feeding on mulberry leaves. The berries that grow on these trees are also fine — you can use them to make a tincture that will chase every ailment right out of your body at once!
You scratch the back of your head wondering whether you really need those cocoons that badly. You'll have to gather a mind-boggling number of chrysalises to get a cut of cloth!
You remember your father's lessons — he showed you little young growth on the mulberry and said that if you see such shoots, the year will definitely be a warm one.
You pick a chrysalis from a branch, thinking that you must by no means let the butterfly hatch. Its noxious saliva will burn a hole in the cocoon, rendering it worthless.

You suddenly find yourself musing on what kind of threads the gods use for measuring out our fates. Or could it be to each their own — flaxen threads for the peasants, wool for the warriors, and silk for the king?

You stare in confusion and then recollect that whenever you see an open wound, you have to cauterize it with red-hot iron. Otherwise the body around it will blacken and deaden. And then the blackness will spread to the rest of the body.
Oh dear! At any rate, you need to use a liquid that kills all illnesses. You should wipe it with urine. Drinking a urine tincture wouldn't hurt, either, but there's no one to make it here…
You hurry to help, but you don't know where to begin. Healers have something that works against pain! What could it be? Belladonna or opium usually, but there's nowhere to procure either right now!
The only thing you remember is how to treat a wound left by a poisoned arrow or javelin. You cauterize it with iron, and then seal the wound with wax. That's the surest cure.

A talisman would come in handy just now — an iron rectangle with symbols written upon it. You remember how this amulet saved your life with something other than magic once — it shattered the arrowhead that would have ended up piercing your chest otherwise!
Dear old mother was so good at bandaging people! I wish I could remember what she taught me!
You look at the body in front of you perplexedly. Where do you begin? A spell against wounds? Or tying a damaged limb to a stick? Or should you use red-hot iron?

You recollect what few things you know about healing: the first thing to do with a wound is to suck out the blood. If a bone is broken, you should tie it to a stick. If the soul has left the body, you should burn some hair or a bone near the nose.

That's nothing! Some were chopped in half in such a way that the head would still blink its eyes while the feet had already run their last. The guy had no idea there was just half of him left, and you kept mum, too.

You think you've seen worse things in your life! Just to recall the wholesale slaughter of the first battles for the Empire's eastern borders. The ground ran red with blood, and the crows flew over the wounded like a black cloud, but even their cawing was drowned out by the yells and the groans… It is as though the rocks had opened up, and everyone was given a glimpse of hell.
All right, you take care! You'll live until you die — that thing should heal in no time!

The Eastern reaches, now — that was something else! They attacked and, by golly, they crushed our army! I still remember how they galloped on, with their horses ramming through our ranks, and how their hooves crushed skulls like eggshells.

Our sawbones was really something! He'd give you a stick to chew on and start twisting your limbs into shape. And is the arm or a leg was beyond healing, he'd just chop it off with an axe, and that was that. Some would grind their teeth into powder with that stick — not everyone can pull through something like that.

It is unpleasant, of course, but nothing that couldn't be fixed. You should have seen this guy who had half his head smashed with a stone from a slingshot — you could even see his mashed brains. He didn't seem to mind too much — he even smiled.
A nice drink to warm you up, that's what we need — the spirits will instantly spread through your blood, making your body hale and your spirit merry!
You must have felt icy paws scratching deep inside? That's fine — we'll burn them with fire, and let them search for another soul!

This is nothing compared to what I've seen with my own eyes! Some would have their stomachs slashed open, with their guts falling into the dust. Others had their heads chopped off — the head flies some 20 feet away, and the body drops down right there next to you. There's nothing you can do but press on and try to avoid blinking.
If you let every wind drop you down like that, you won't get anywhere. Pull yourself together — we'll have mead at their funeral yet!
You stretch out your feet, thinking it would be really nice to stretch them towards a bright fire… The warmth would spread through your body, and there would be steam coming from your wet clothes…
You sit down and stretch with great relish, and then scratch with gusto. Isn't it nice to relax sometimes!
You stretch so hard your joints crackle, and give a wide yawn. The weary muscles are filling with languor.

You stretch out your feet and wiggle your toes. You think that a comfortable pair of shoes would come in handy — you could make them, perhaps, or maybe someone will trade you a pair. You dream of strong brown leather softly gripping your foot, with snug-fitting straps on top.

Some lunch sure wouldn't be amiss now! Smoky pork and sweet-smelling bread hot from the oven, washed down by a good swig of beer… Food of the gods. You wallow in your daydream with your eyes shut tight in anticipation.
Isn't it nice to sit down like that? you think to yourself. "I don't really feel like I'm myself when I haven't had any rest."

The moment you sit down like that, all sorts of things occur to you. Do gods observe you every moment, and if they do, where were they looking when you cut your finger with a knife a few days ago? And is it true there are rivers underground just like ours, and also cities? And does the Sacred Tree really support all nine worlds upon itself?
You sit down and press your palms against the ground — you hope the God of the Netherworld will share some of his power with you this way.
You shut your eyes for a moment, thinking to yourself that you shouldn't fall asleep. But the sleep glues your eyelids together better than any wax, and you begin to doze off.
You rub your shoulders thinking you could do with some better clothes.
You think of how pleasant it is to spend time with others from time to time — to sit by the fire, telling tall tales, and recalling things that happened in your glorious past.

You see an ant on the ground, hurrying about its own business. You wonder how such a small ant can have enough strength to carry a straw that is ten times heavier. Does it rely on higher powers? You gingerly lift the straw with your thumb and forefinger to lighten the insect's burden. But the ant drops the straw — apparently, it is accustomed to take care of everything by itself or with the aid of its kin.
You pick up a wood chip with your fingers and start doodling on the ground. You look at the doodles as though they were symbols that you can decipher.

You look at your hands and see wiry veins covering the backs of your hands like rivers of blue. Hard work spares no one — your skin gets rough, your arms get veined, and you get black grime underneath your fingernails.
You remember what your father used to say: "Find time for work, but be sure to leave an hour for leisure." The wise old man knew life well.

Your heart seems to be skipping beats in your chest like a small fluttering bird flinging itself against your ribs as though they were the bars of a cage. You really have to take a break — you've been working non-stop and are now feeling like a horse that's been ridden down.

You like to just sit there and daydream without being disturbed. You can dream of so many things — for instance, you can dream you are someone else; someone with lands and cattle, for example. All you have to do is wave a hand if you want a chalice of mead — or someone to scratch your heels. You wave your hand in a commanding manner, forgetting there is no one there to rush to your beckon.

You take the chance offered by your momentary respite and fish a pebble that you found in the evening out of the folds of your clothes. It is a worthless pebble by any account — fit to be a child's toy and little else; and yet it is too beautiful and too smooth, and cannot help wanting to roll it in your fingers. You admire the intricate pattern of stripes on its sides, as smooth as if they were polished.

You rub your eyelids hard with your fingers — your eyes must be tired, or the wind may have blown some sand into them. Your eyelids remain shut, but you still see the wobbly black and orange circles left by finger pressure.
You examine the ground in order to check for fresh tracks — perhaps some light paws have left their prints somewhere.
It occurs to you that it would be easier to set a second trap for small prey than to go hunting. A trap can save a lot of effort!
You set your trap and think that catching an animal requires a lot of patience. The beast has to get used to the place, smell everything, and eventually decide everything is safe…

You mark the place where you set the trap and think you should check it more often. Sometimes you fail to check the trap in due time, and the hare or the quail has already escaped! Either that, or it got eaten by a larger beast.
You think of how important it is to find a good place for your trap. A narrow path with overhanging branches is perfect — the beast will tear through the shrubs and will definitely get into the trap.
Startling a hare is another good method. It will run into any trap in its terror, no matter how roughly you may make it.

You recollect a lesson taught by a hunter acquaintance — you may never change anything you see. You cannot break any twigs or walk over any tracks. If it's a hazel grove, you cannot make your trap out of pine or birch wood.
You examine the trap you've just set and cover it with leaves and dirt. This should make the whole thing more reliable.
It occurs to you that you might want to use some smoke from a fire to make sure no trace of human smell remains anywhere.
You check whether the trap you've set is sturdy enough. Any minute defect can be used by the animal to its advantage. It will break the trap and run away, much to your chagrin.
You have found a tall and supple tree for your trap — this way the beast or the bird will be hoisted right up, and no forest predator will be able to reach it.

A fat quail would be just right. If you bake it in an open fire, you'll eat it up in no time, crunching the bones away! A hare is fine, too, provided it isn't too stringy. A hungry belly will rejoice at anything!
You set your trap muttering a hasty prayer — may the gods hear it and grant you a good haul.
You wonder whether there may not be enough bait. However, forest beasts have a keen sense of smell. They can smell anything from a long way off, even crumbs.
The pole that you intended to use for the bait unbends suddenly and slaps you right in the face. The left side of your face feels totally numb.

You anticipate how a fat hare will get caught in your trap and it occurs to you that you should test its strength. What if the hare proves too heavy and manages to run away? You should also use a thicker pole.

You set your trap right on a path that has fresh animal tracks. You know that during the summer such tracks are usually moist — there can even be water inside them. During the winter they crumble at the lightest touch.

You bend, and then straighten up again, trying to estimate whether the beast will see your contraption. As you keep on doing those exercises, you scratch your face as you stick it right into a bush, and, after an irate oath, you decide that the trap is probably not visible to animals.
You test the pole's flexibility by bending and unbending it. Willow branches are best — there is so much moisture in them that you could probably tie a knot in the branch.
You examine the tracks — the ones at the top are wide, and the ones at the bottom are next to each other. These were obviously left by a hare. However, the tracks are rather old.
You bend down to take a closer look at the complex pattern of prints left by birds. They are fine and intricate, just like red embroidered patterns on women's dresses.
You try to leave your own footprint on the path out of sheer curiosity. But it turns out very vague and hardly visible at all — the ground here is dense and compact.

Hares are cunning beasts! They will never just run away from a hunter — they will leave a veritable labyrinth of tracks. Then you have to make a real effort to track them and to find out where they are hiding.

You think that hunting is all about showing more cunning than the other party. A hare is clever — it winds and doubles its tracks. But the hunter is no fool, either. You need a particular kind of cunning — don't stop as you read the tracks, or the bunny will think that it's found and run as fast as it can. What you need to do is deceive the beast — just lift your feet and put them down again, but don't go anywhere. It will never be the wiser.

You slip on a rotten piece of wood and flail your arms around as though you were trying to get airborne. You grab branches with your fingers and arch your back. You have managed to keep your balance, after all, but your fingers are all scratched by the branches.

A sharp pain makes you stop in your tracks. You lift your left leg and rub it with your hands. Your foot has failed to avoid a sharp stone, which injures the sole badly. How are you supposed to keep walking now?

You remember a hunter who was following a track in just as foolhardy a manner, claiming the most dangerous thing one might encounter there were a quail. He ended up disappearing in the woods without a trace! Only the forest spirits know what fate befell him.
The strange sounds makes you shiver. Is that an owl hooting? Or an invisible forest spirit flying on wings of the night? You no longer care about tracks, studying the sky anxiously.
You startled a magpie, and it has started to chatter loudly. You throw a ball of earth into the bird — if it carries on like this, it will scare all the animals away!
A twig snaps under your foot, breaking the silence. You kick the piece of wood in frustration — it has announced your presence to all the animals around.
You look at the ground and notice an unusual lump that shines in the soft light. You pick it up — one doesn't find useful items like that every day.

A lizard darts off from underneath your feet. You stomp your foot to catch its tail. But you are too clumsy, and the lizard is too agile. It hides in the rocks, and you realize that you have stomped all over the tracks.

You feel something fall under the neck of your garment. A beetle! You feel it flounce and kick in every direction, trying to escape. The way you jump around to shake it out of your clothes resembles an elaborate dance.
You take an awkward step and twist your foot. You land on your rear end in surprise, rubbing your sprained ankle. If you carry on like this, you can end up lame!
You find a heavy pine cone on the path. Its scales are stuck together by resin, which makes your fingers sticky, but the nuts you find inside are soft and sweet, with a milky taste.

Your foot sinks underground, and you barely manage to avoid breaking it. It may be someone's burrow or just a hole in the ground — or, maybe, it was dug by the mischievous spirits of the forest for fun. You shake your fist in the air, menacing no one in particular and everyone in general.

You examine the ground — the tracks appear to belong to a bear, the master of the forest. It will learn of your invasion instantly, and then it will keep its eye on you. If you think you're hunting it, you're deluded. He's got you in his sights.

It's fun to look for tracks, but you have to be careful! The mischievous spirits of the forest can deceive everyone, including experienced hunters — they'll leave all sorts of tracks to make you run around in circles, and then you'll get lost in the thicket!

If you come across bear tracks, you won't mistake them for anything — they even resemble human tracks a tiny bit. They are round and have five toes, but each toe ends with a dagger as long as a human palm!
You take a closer look at the ground — it seems as though you have noticed boar tracks. They are elongated and split in two, like grains of wheat. But these are rather old.
You see marks of sharp claws on trees — a bear must have had real fun marking its territory. Now you have to be vigilant wherever you go.
You see that the leaves are trampled, but you cannot discern any tracks. You should examine trees for tracks — you might find a mark on the bark or a tuft of wool on one of the branches.
You trip over a protruding branch and fall forward, landing right on your face. Your knees are raw and your forehead is injured. (knockdown)

You see something that resembles dog tracks on the ground. What would a dog be doing here? It's a wolf! You remember tales about humans that can turn into wolves — those are a great deal more dangerous to come across than actual wolves.
You see old grain-like tracks on the ground. It's a boar! But they are stretched into a single line — the beast must have been in a hurry. Who was following it?
You inspect the grass you see. If the grains were eaten tidily, it must have been a bear. Boars chew quickly and sloppily — they eat on the run.
You seem to have found wolf tracks. Ah well — a single wolf is no danger in the forest, for it will always try to pass a human by. But if you run into a pack during the winter, you're a goner!
The silence is broken by a sudden crack of a twig. You shiver and stand still. Which forest animal could have broken it? Oh, it was your foot…
You look out for tracks, musing on which animal is the most dangerous — a bear, or a wounded boar? The battle that plays out in your head always ends the same way — the hunter gets torn to pieces.

Bears are more intelligent than many a human being! They mess their tracks up so much you can hardly find them. The hunters said it can also attract a moose with a cry that resembles that of a female moose, and pull fishermen's nets out onto the shore. A most cunning beast indeed!
Apart from looking around constantly, you keep smelling the wind. For instance, boar droppings have a sharp unpleasant smell — you'll be able to feel it from the distance of twenty feet.
It's best to avoid meeting an irate boar face to snout. And in the winter they fashion themselves armor out of tree resin — that's when they're at their most furious and hard-sided.

You see tracks of large clawed paws, but they suddenly stop as if by magic. What unknown powers could have borne the beast away? Or have the forest spirits tricked you by making you run around in circles? You spit across your shoulder for the mirage to disappear.
You see torn-off bark high above your head. "What a giant!" you think to yourself. It's best to avoid a bear like that. Or, perhaps, it wasn't a bear in the first place.
You keep your eyes on the ground, taking in the powerful and inapproachable atmosphere of the forest. This is where one's proximity to the spirits of nature is felt the most acutely.

Blood drips from your knife as you take a satisfied look at the fruits of your labor — the most important thing here is to bleed the carcass well. That requires delivering a precise strike to the heart or slashing the main blood vessels. That's something you can do very aptly, after all.

You straighten wearily, thinking this is exactly what your father had taught you: move the knife across the belly, from the head to the tail, with a steady hand. Then make circles around the neck and the limbs — it's easier to skin the carcass that way. Good job!
You're looking at the skinned carcass thinking which part of it to bury in the ground to placate God. Heart will probably be best — it embodies life itself, after all.

You are pleased with your work — you didn't waste any time with the carcass. After all, it's imperative that you get to business immediately, as soon as the spark of life leaves the body. Otherwise the meat might go stale.

You carefully wipe the knife with a tuft of grass. The knife is your closest ally. If you need to butcher and skin a carcass, you need to choose the sharpest knife you have. A dull one won't make it through the ribs. Nor will it cut tough meat — that of a moose, for instance.

You put your knife back in its place and think that sometime you need all your skill to skin an animal. If you need the skin to be whole, you have to be very careful — especially from the side of the snout. You need to touch the skull with the knife very gently, as though you were kissing it, and the eyelids need to be pulled down, lest they get damaged.
You think you heard a hissing sound when you were cutting the meat. You inspect the carcass carefully — if you pierce the stomach with your knife, the meat may spoil instantly.

You stop for a breather, remembering the way they hunted back home. If you went far on your hunt, you wouldn't be able to bring just any beast back. Hunters would use their knives with great skill to separate the meat from the bones so as not to break their backs. They would bring the meat home and bury the bones in the ground.

You inspect the butchered carcass with pleasure — you've done well; the bladder is right here, and it's completely undamaged. There are hunters of poor skill who would empty everything into the meat — the guts as well as the bladder.

You drop the knife on the ground and inspect your palm, which you have sliced with your knife in haste. It is all covered in blood — yours as well as the animal's, which makes it impossible for you to tell just how big the wound is.

You have finished work and were just about to stand up when you noticed a scar on the skin — a bald patch without any fur. You trace out the mark with your finger — it looks as though it had been left by an arrow.

You look at your bloodied hands thinking just how cruel this world is to its children — everyone has to eat somebody else to survive. Then you shrug: it's either eat or be eaten, after all. And being eaten is much worse any way you look at it.
You weren't very tidy when you were skinning the carcass, since you were trying to accomplish it before the deathly chill sets in. Once the carcass chills, it becomes much harder to skin it.
You feel an unpleasant sensation on your face — blood had squirted on it when you were cutting one of the major arteries. Now it has dried up and formed a scab-like patch on your skin.

You wipe the sweat from your brow with a bloodied hand, trying to catch your breath. You remember the two traditional ways of skinning a carcass. The skin of a deer's or a moose's carcass is peeled off as a single sheet, but when you skin a hare, you have to roll it up inside out.

You rest, recollecting one of the customs of the nomadic tribes that used to roam along the Empire's borders. Even within the Empire you find people who call beef and goat meet black, presuming it to be of low quality. They prefer to slaughter rams and horses for their meals.

You wipe your knife thinking of how aptly the steppe dwellers butcher animal carcasses. They don't cut bone — instead, they slice the carcass where its joints are. You slash it a few times and that's that!
You barely manage to get up and you wipe your brow. This wasn't one of your better days, and it has taken you longer than usual to take care of the carcass

You take a good look at the construction site. You chuckle inside — there was a time when the foundation of any house had to have blood sprinkled over it. The tradition is dying out — besides, the state religion does not condone human sacrifice. But modern builders occasionally slaughter a lamb at the construction site, at any rate. It's safer that way.
You remember a folk belief — if a builder harbors ill thoughts against someone, he puts a spell on a stone or a log in the new house. There is no worse curse, and nothing can save the unfortunate.

You remember that back in the days of yore they would bury some poor soul alive when they built a palace or a fortress. Right in the foundation. Their spirit was supposed to guard the townsfolk or the owner of the castle from the enemies.
You think of all the different methods of construction. Back in the day there were houses with earthen walls. All you need to do is to tamp it down as much as you can.
You remember what your father always used to say: "There must be a solid foundation under any endeavor." So true. And especially true of buildings.
It occurs to you that building a house is like making a living creature. And the power in your hands matches that of the gods, who grant the gift of life.

You examine the ground under your feet — you appear to have made no mistake. It doesn't crumble, and it isn't damp, so the ground waters must be running deep. So you have chosen a safe place, after all.
You touch a tree with your hand and think of the old custom that trees for building should be felled in the winter — while the tree sleeps, all of its water is sucked into the ground.

You also think that forefathers would never permit anyone to use unlucky trees for construction works — those split in two by lighting, for example, or the ones felled by the wind. Stands to reason — who knows what effect it could have on your house?
You examine the construction site and think with satisfaction that you have chosen a good place. Not at a crossroads, not at the site of a fire, and not at a graveyard.

You scratch the back of your head wondering whether you may have been too hasty with the construction. After all, back in the olden days they would call in diviners, who would observe the flight of birds or toss some sheep bones around to find the best place for construction.
You remember how your grandfather would put coins into the foundation for prosperity. And if you put bread in every corner, the residents will never go hungry in their life.

You press your palm against the tree — it seems warm. You think that the larch is the best tree for construction. It is sturdy and durable, and lasts many decades. However, you haven't seen any hereabouts.

You wonder what kind of timber you should use for the top of the building. Tastes differ, but your favorite wood comes from aspens. They are easy to chop and resilient to rain; the wood sparkles with gold in the sun and with crimson at sunset.

Tell me what you will, but I prefer coniferous trees to their deciduous counterparts, whatever they are. The timber is strong and resistant to moisture. The silver fir, for instance, has a pleasant smell; it also keeps you warm better than any other tree.

You shave off a thin layer of wood and examine the shaving. Is it supple enough? Can you tie it into a knot? If it crumbles into dust, the wood is finally mature and dry enough. That is why they also keep timber under canopies — to expose them to the wind that will blow all the moisture out of them.
Wood is easier to use in construction, of course. Stone is more trouble, but it keeps warmth inside during the winter and coolness in the summer.
Wood makes the habitation smell better; on the other hand, neither fire, nor rain can do anything to stone. Fancy someone try to destroy you when you hide behind stone walls!
You think that you truly shouldn't skimp on construction materials — the thicker the wall, the sturdier and the more reliable it is. And in these troubled times one has to think of protection first.
You think there will not be enough stone and lumber for building a house with proper framework. What you need is a mixture of clay and hay or dry rush, depending on where you live.
You think that you are a different person when you're hungry, and it's best not to stand in your way — you could eat a whole moose with his skin right now.
You swallow a bite and feel it drop down into the greedy and empty stomach that contracts in anticipation of food.

Oh, this is a far cry from my dear mom's cooking. That was no food — that was nectar! The golden juices of the meat would trickle down the chin; the fingers and the face would be covered in grease, and the smell was so powerful you could cut it with a knife and put slices in your mouth.
Not the kind of food one dreams of right now. Oh, for a fat chunk of pork, or even a young lamb — fresh from the spit, hot and smoky…

The bite you take in haste gets stuck in your throat and you convulsively try to cough it out and catch a breath. Your body is shaken by coughing spasms. The ill-fated chunk is finally out. You wipe the sweat from your brow.
Suddenly there's an itch in your nose and you sneeze. Your full mouth is like a geyser spewing half-chewed food.

There is a wasp buzzing around your lips, attracted by the smell of food. You try to wave the pesky insect away, and it retaliates by biting you in the lip. You find that it isn't that easy to chew when your lip is swallen.

A meal is always a good thing. Still, I hope I won't get stomach cramps like the previous time. All the innards felt like they were being turned inside out, as if the very soul was about to have a rendezvous with the ancestors come morning.

You swallow the food greedily. Your teeth grind and tear it. One of your cheeks suddenly gets in between your teeth, which work as grindstones. You jerk your head in sudden pain and are forced to chew with more care, trying to favor the damaged side and avoid having food touch it.
A piece of food gets into one of your teeth, and it feels as if it were struck by lightning. You grab your cheek — the tooth worm must be as hungry as you, devouring your flesh greedily.
Finally you truly understand the wise words of your mother: "Hunger is the best seasoning to any food."
You feel a sudden weakness in your body, and a sweat comes onto your brow. "Those were some cramps," you think, hoping fervently that, perhaps, at least this time the illness will pass you by.
You hear a loud rumble in your intestines. Well, what can you say? A hungry belly has no ears and heeds no words. The only language one's stomach understands is the language of food.

You swallow a bite with satisfaction, without having even chewed it properly, and remember an old saying: the stomach is an ingrate and remembers no good deeds. No point discussing yesterday's dinner with it.
You dally for a moment, wary of another stomach cramp. Then you open your mouth wide: whatever jumps into your mouth is good for you!
You think it feels a lot better once you have dined, no matter how much you eat. And it feels warmer, too.
You finish chewing the last bite and think that it's much better this way. You cannot stop that gaping hole in the stomach with anything — all you can do is give it food.

At the end of my journey, I can see through time, my eyes blinded with tears.
I see the star of our hopes
the emperor who once brought peace and prosperity to our house,
who built a powerful empire, and united tribes from all walks of life.
I see an epoch of overall happiness.
And now, that all lies in ruin.
The old gods had arisen
brothers picked up arms against brothers
mankind clung to each other's throats, ruled by a state of anarchy
and Mother Nature took her revenge by showering plague and famine upon us.
Evil is walking in this world
leaving nothing but dead cities and pillaged settlements behind.
The land is lifeless and barren...
But... maybe... there is life on that distant, forgotten land
where only few once dared to venture
those whom we would once call madmen.
You are one of these madmen now.
What destiny awaits you?
Will you find your way or disappear trying?
Will you rise to glory or fade into obscurity?
No one knows.
Only time will tell.

Ferryman

<font:Open Sans Bold Italic:16>Abella<font:Open Sans:16> — a mysterious continent praised in the old legends.
On Abella you can become a distinguished craftsman, a victorious commander, a famous merchant, or just a common laborer. Create your own kingdom and try to make the entire continent bow to your will or in opposite — find a quiet corner in a middle of nowhere to live a quiet life away from nasty neighbors.
<font:Open Sans Bold Italic:16>Illa-newydd<font:Open Sans:16> — you are on, consists of 49 separate islands. It is a strange place specifically created and designed by the Gods to test and measure humans if they are worthy of a new life on Abella.
If you and your friends find yourselves washed on the shores of different islands after the shipwreck, try to look for a ferryman, he can help you to get together.

<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Interface Modes
In <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Freelook Mode<spop> you can move and look around
<spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Cursor Mode<spop> is activated when you open a window or press Tab
<color:666666>You automatically switch to Freelook Mode if there are no open windows left on the screen
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Your Inventory
All of your non-equipped items are stored in your inventory. <color:666666>Your current and maximum inventory weight are displayed in the window header.
<spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Right-click<spop> on an item to interact with it.
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Attributes and Equipment
Your attributes and equipped items are shown in this window.
Mouse over an attribute or item to learn more about it.
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Interacting with Objects

<spush><color:666666>You can interact with many objects in the world of Life is Feudal.<spop>
Press <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>RMB<spop> while looking at an object (or ground) to open a context menu and see what you can do.

Press <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>RMB<spop> in the context menu to assign a default action. Now you won't have to find the action on the list – it will be performed when you press <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>LMB<spop> or <font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>E.
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Gathering Basic Resources
<spush><color:666666>Flint, plant fibers, and branches are required to craft primitive tools and materials.

Plant fibers, flint and branches can be found on the ground using the <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Look for Materials<spop> ability.
Branches also can be gathered from medium and major trees using <font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Gather a Branch.
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Item Crafting

<spush><color:666666>Recipes are grouped by the tools required to craft the item.<spop>
Open a recipe to see the resources you need. Press the "Craft" button to craft the item.
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Changing the Landscape (Terraforming)

<spush><color:666666>In order to dig, you need a shovel. When you dig, the level of the ground is reduced and the soil you dig up is added to your inventory.<spop>
To see the level of the ground around you, press <font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>F3.

In order to <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:cccccc>raise the ground level<spop> you need at least 15 units of soil. You can just drop it from your inventory or target the ground and use <font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Raise Ground Level.

In order to <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:cccccc>flat a tile<spop> relative to another one, stand on a tile of the desired height and use the <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Flatten<spop> ability on the adjacent tile. Use the ability until the ground level becomes identical. Flattened tiles are highlighted in green.
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Construction

<spush><color:666666>In order to build structures, you need a hammer. Most structures can only be built on flattened tiles.<spop>
Begin construction by using the <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Construct<spop> ability (you need to have unlocked the Construction skill).
To complete the construction process, add all required resources to the structure's foundation and select <font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c> Build.
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Gathering Resources with Tools

Basic construction resources: <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>wood, clay and stone<spop>.
To chop down a tree, equip an axe, target tree, and select <font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Cut down.

In order to gather stone, you need a pickaxe. Use the <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Dig Tunnel<spop> ability on rocky ground.
In order to gather clay, you need a shovel. Use the <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Lower Ground Level<spop> ability on a clay pit.
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Prospecting and Mining

Ore is required to craft items made of metal. Finding ore isn't easy, but if you find some you will gain access to a large quantity of metal.
To find ore, use the <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Prospect...<spop> ability and set the search area using the slider.
<color:666666>If there is ore nearby you will receive a message about it. Once you have found the ore you will need a pickaxe in order to mine it.
Use the <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Dig a Tunnel<spop> ability to reach the ore deposit.
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Combat Basics

To draw a weapon from your belt, press <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>1 or 2<spop>. To draw a weapon from your back, press <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>3 or 4<spop>. Once you have drawn a weapon you will enter a <font:Open Sans Bold:20>combat stance.

<spush><color:666666>While in a combat stance you take less damage and can attack, but your stamina drains more quickly.<spop>
Move the mouse to adjust the direction of your swing. You can perform left swing, right swing, thrust and overhead attacks.

<spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Damage types.<spop> Different parts of a weapon inflict different types of damage. The handle of an axe deals blunt damage, while the edge deals chopping damage.

<spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Blunt damage<spop> is the only non-fatal type of damage. Blunt damage drains Soft HP, but not Hard HP. When your Soft HP reaches zero you are knocked out and will regain consciousness after a while.
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Hunger

<spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Keep an eye on your hunger level.<spop> Once your hunger level reaches zero you will begin to lose Hard HP and your Soft Stamina will stop regenerating.
To avoid staying hungry, pick apples from the nearest tree or try to find edible berries and roots using <font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Find Something Edible.
<spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>The quality of your food<spop> is very important. If you eat dishes with many ingredients you will acquire skills more quickly.
Simple food can be cooked over a campfire. If you want to cook complex dishes you will need a kitchen and the <font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Cooking skill.
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Death

If you die you lose a portion of your skill points based on your <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Alignment<spop> level. <color:666666>For 10 minutes after death your movements will be slower and Soft Stamina will be consumed faster.<spop>
You can <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>bind to house<spop> to respawn there.
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Alignment System and Consequences
<color:666666>Alignment system is designed to protect upstanding players against dishonest ones.

<spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Players with positive Alignment<spop> lose fewer skill points when they die and have a higher chance to successfully perform religious rites such as Bless with God's Mercy.
<spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Players with negative Alignment<spop> lose more skill points when they die and have almost no chance of successfully performing abilites linked to religion.

<spush><color:666666>Alignment can be reduced by attacking other players, stealing, and invading someone else's territory.<spop>
Alignment cannot fall below -49 due to any action other than <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>murder.<spop>
Alignment can be increased by the daily "Praise your God!" prayer.
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Homecoming

To bind to a house, use the <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Claim as Your Home<spop> ability on the house.
If you bound to house you will be able to return to it using the <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Prayer for Homecoming<spop> ability. You will also return to your home when you die.
<color:666666>Your inventory items are not transferred with you if you use the Prayer for Homecoming ability in Life is Feudal MMO. Only the equipped ones will be transferred with you.
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Hunting

You can track wild animals by using the <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Track Peaceful Animal<spop> ability on the ground. If there are wild animals nearby you will see their tracks.
As your <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Hunter<spop> skill increases you will gain the ability to track aggressive animals.
In order to hunt successfully you will need a <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>ranged weapon<spop>.
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Fishing

To catch fish, equip a fishing pole and use the <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Fish<spop> ability on the surface of a body of water.
A large variety of edible fish live in bodies of water.
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Animal Lore

Depending on their species, tamed animals can be placed in a coop, barn, or stable, where they will multiply and produce useful resources such as <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>eggs, milk, wool<spop>, etc.

Keep track of how much your animals eat and the quality of their food. If the pollution level exceeds 100%% animals will start dying from poor hygiene. If animals don't have enough food they will start dying from hunger.

Rabbits and grouses can be caught in <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>snares<spop>. Place snares on forest soil and wait for animals to be trapped by them.
Cows, pigs, sheep, and horses can be tamed using the <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Tame<spop> ability. Stock up on apples or carrots and try taming animals rather than hunting them.
<font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Alchemy

<spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Mix herbs<spop> in a mortar or on an alchemist's table to learn their effects. <color:666666>Herbs and reagents can be used to craft preparations, potions, poisons, and useful alchemical ingredients such as flux, flammable naphtha, and flavors for improving food.
The same herbs will have different effects when used by different players. <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Trade herbs<spop> with other players to get the combinations you need.

<spush><font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Mortar and Pestle<spop>
Press <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Backspace<spop> to learn about Alchemy

<spush><font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Animal Lore<spop>
Press <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Backspace<spop> to learn about animal husbandry

<spush><font:PT Serif Bold:24><color:b2801c>Alignment<spop>
Press <spush><font:Open Sans Bold:20><color:b2801c>Backspace<spop> to learn about Alignment system

That's all for now, you can go.

That's all for now, you can go.
