You cannot create a Guild or a Personal Claim in the current world. Try it once more, when you'll get on the Abella.
So you seen that washtub already, eh? Yes, we are. A stupid business. Better to use the wood on coffins!
I have heard that the gods desire a diversity of things.
I have khtynka for you. Shall we drink?
We have already spoken.
I have been cast by the waves onto the shores of this wilderness. Thus I seek the elder. Are you he?
Ah, another one...
I have heard it said you possess secret knowledge. That you are able to kindle a fire. Might you teach me?
Greetings.

Ah, another one.
Go to the village. Yet this is not Abella.

Ah, another one.
Go to the village. Yet this is not Abella.
Not Abella? What? Sure looks like, being an island and all.
See the World Tree around?
Something tall over there, and a pillar of light rising to heaven...
You see the light, then... You, brother, lost your mind I see. Go to the village, they will help you.
Well, then I will get going.
You have any fireleaf?
Here you go. Should be dry by now.
Many thanks.
So, can you tell me something?
What is that village about?
Go have a look. I guess we are not alone here. Mayhap they have a karve.
Who is this hanging here?
Strange people. Mayhap priests of some foreign god, mayhap warriors. They have been presented as a sacred offering. Yet, we hardly managed to do it...
And what's that tower in the distance, and the light?
Do not be a fool.
Alright, have a seat
Asveh, brother. How are you?
We have to get out. Soon.
How?
There is no life here. Hell no this is Abella.

I left them there, in that hell. I didn't listen... And I lost everything.
But this is not the land of apples.
We must leave...
*The grave digger wavers and has trouble keeping himself from belching. As you approach, he frowns, trying to focus his eyes on you*
Asoveh Svefnii!
Asoveh dendodeh! Have you spoken with our elder yet?
Asoveh dendodeh! Have you spoken with our elder yet?
No. To what end?

You haven't spoken with him means I won't be speaking with you.
He's in charge here, talk to him. He'll look at you. Be you good man or, as our Accur says, be you Gloomdung. If'n he decides you're fine, then we talk.

You haven't spoken with him means I won't be speaking with you.
He's in charge here, talk to him. He'll look at you. Be you good wench or, as our Accur says, be you Gloomdung. If'n he decides you're fine, then we talk.
Okeh, off I go.
We have spoken.
We have spoken.
You seen the el– elder?
You seen the el– elder?
Nah.

Then go!
He's in charge here, talk to him. He'll look at you and savvy. If'n he decides you're fine, then come b- back and we'll talk.

Then go!
He's in charge here, talk to him. He'll look at you and savvy. If'n he decides you're fine, then come b- back and we'll talk.
I have.
I have.
Then te– tell me. What do you want?
Then te– tell me. What do you want?
You're a gravedigger, right? I can dig something up... or bury it.
This is your place, then. I have something for you.
This is your place, then. I have something for you.
What is it?

I've heard say that here in the earth, if you dig deep down, you find the miracle called the baromsag, a wonder of the gods from long ago. The islands stand on them and that keeps them from sinking, the Accurs say.
So go where you will out the village and dig a great pit. Look close at all you see, and perhaps you'll be lucky and find this wonder.
One more thing: a baromsag is mostly found in clay.
Got it.
Got it.
Any more que– questions?
What is this, uh, burmasag? What's it for?

If you place a baromsaggen in a special hole in the hull of a gavran, no witchcraft can sink it! I hear tell the Khoors add it to their soup. Our cook do, to be sure!
So find this baromsag and you'll have honor and praise from all. We'll add it to our vessel so it may not sink and instead have us safely away.
Yeah...
So where can I find a shovel?
So helpless, eh? Go to Ulf, I will not give you mine.
So helpless, eh? Go to Ulf, I will not give you mine.
So, I dug the pit.
So, I dug the pit.
And did you find the kudritt?
And did you find the kudritt?
What the... kudritt-bullshit? You said I needed to find a burmasagen!
Right, right, 'tis another name for the baromsag. And the Khoors call it "teneglel." Many names. But did you find one?
Right, right, 'tis another name for the baromsag. And the Khoors call it "teneglel." Many names. But did you find one?
I found not a cursed thing. Just clay and dirt.
I found not a cursed thing. Just clay and dirt.

Okay. Then, listen here a tip.
Of times you will spend digging, this is the first of many. We all live by the shovel, for sustenance, for shelter, for defense, it all starts from the earth.
Wait, what about that magic burm... thing I was looking for?
Wait, what about that magic bergamot thing I was looking for?
You happen to find one, bring it here straightaway, heh. But remember that it is a mighty secret. Tell no one!
And one more, about land works, then tell me...
I understand. So, when will you teach me about forming the earth?

Ah. Listen up.
Pits are always good, but you need more. If'n you be wanting to construct something, you first flatten the ground so 'tis straight and not inclining itself to one side. And falling come night.
Or maybe you want to build a mound so your enemies have to climb up to reach you. A shovel is what you need, be it wood or metal.

Or say you need a fortress wall, not a common one but on a slope. Then a shovel you need. First, take it and flatten the earth but with the incline you seek. Only then may your builder make the said wall on that spot.
Got it?

Or say you need a fortress wall, not along a flat place. Then a shovel you need to shape first the earth to the incline you seek. Then you build your wall.
Understand?
I will remember that. Any other wisdom for me?
I will remember that. Any other wisdom for me?

Plenty more!
Treat your shovel with care, for it is fragile and prone to breaking should you be too clumsy. Beware of chips and cracks in it, and sharpen it with regularity. A wooden shovel will dig but little before it loses all its usefulness.
Wrap your hands with rags, or gloves, if'n you can. And mayhap wrap the handle with something, to save your hands.
Time is passing, and my words have been many. Go on, now, gods be with you.
Thank you.
I'll get going.
*The grave digger is whispering something, paying you no heed*
Why are you acting so odd?
Woe is me, my brew is out, and I cannot make more. Would you bring me some mushrooms instead?
...mushrooms?

Yes, mushrooms, with the tiny nubs. Good for chewing. I cannot be soberminded in this place! In trade I'll make you a wonderful grave, not like these with their kneeling poses, but fit for an emperor, you'll see! Full size, with outstretched arms.
So you'll bring me my mushrooms, yes?
I'm not about to head to the grave anytime soon, but thank you for the offer.

Perhaps you are not "about to," but as the gods will it.
So will you bring me my mushrooms? I have no strength to stretch out my damned existence on this island any further without them. Mushrooms!
What is so bad about this island? The sun is shining, the grass is green, the earth is rich. Build a dung hut, or better, a stone one, and live here. Or is there something I'm missing?

So ignorant! Our sun, Amate the Shining, never ceases to give light, that is truth. She spreads her rays in the sky, feeds the earth and grass beneath.
But this island is cursed. Elsewhere men build houses to stand for centuries. Here, if'n they build, it falls 'ere a short time passes.
And treacherous fog surrounds the land to keep up from sailing away. Thus the gods keep us here.
How about those mushrooms?
Cool it with the mushrooms for one minute! Why don't buildings stay up for long here?

As I say, the island is damned. Or is your hearing dull? Houses here do not stand long. Tombs, though, they last for ages. Good to dig them early. Ah, hold, I understand you, I do!
So you want to be buried with a warhorse? No one has done that yet. Look, our crooked carpenter, our "shipbuilder," wants to be buried with a gavran, the bastard. But only after his third pitcher...

As I say, the island is damned. Or is your hearing dull? Houses here do not stand long. Tombs, though, they last for ages. Good to dig them early. Ah, hold, I understand you, I do!
So you want to be buried with a warhorse? No one has done that yet. Look, our crooked carpenter, our "shipbuilder," wants to be buried with a gavran, the bastard. But only after his third pitcher...
I... I don't have a horse. But I might want a house. Not horse. House.

A master at bargaining, you are! Very well, a house it is. But only a small one, mind you. And no horse! Never have I met someone like you, looking to be buried with a house, not in my life on this earth.
And what about those mushrooms, eh? Will you bring me some?

A master at bargaining, you are! Very well, a house it is. But only a small one, mind you. And no horse! Never have I met someone like you, looking to be buried with a house, not in my life on this earth.
And what about those mushrooms, eh? Will you bring me some?
Mushrooms? Bah. Shroomhead.
I will bring you some mushrooms, Gloom take you. Where do I find them?
In the forest they sit, waiting for me... Or ask the cook. She knows where they are.
Alright. Here I go.
I haven't found any mushrooms for you.
I haven't found any mushrooms for you.
Why, O man, art thou so mean? *sings* Fowl and mean, wretched being!
Why, O woman, art thou so mean? *sings* Fowl and mean, wretched being!
Got it. And I see you found some home brew. Time for me to go, then.
Wait a moment. Listen. Hear that?
Where?
Not where, whom. Them. Hear them whispering?
Hmm.

Right. *rolls eyes*
<font:Open Sans Italic:20>And then rose Svefnii his mighty legs upon the firmament of Elgverden and the firmament did shutter and split and many cities and realms of the Lungs were ruined for upon the world had come the Reaping of the Maiden of the Red Scythe, Johdenandhe

<font:Open Sans Italic:20>And lo, Svefnii gazed upon Elgverden, wreathed in flame and covered in the Sparks of the Lungs. With his eye of flame, he gazed upon it and saw what manner he could use it to his own end.
He did rend Elgverden asunder and one piece was named Sparksvaard.
<font:Open Sans Italic:20>And Sparksvaard became a land of strife and slaughter, Bargerelung, a land replete with collapse, loss, separation, suffering, pain, fear, and death. Velent.

<font:Open Sans Italic:20>Svefnii stretched forth his hand and gathered the brightest Sparks from the chiefest of powerful Lungs. He gathered the Sparks of thousands of thousands, and myriads of myriads. So numerous they were, that in Svefnii's hand there was not found place for them, and they did become stars. Jomfru. And behold, Svefnii formed a sword from the sparks of the Lungs, and it became a ray of light in the darkness.
You a skald?
Huh? Who are you?
Uh, I went looking for mushrooms for you.
Uh, I went looking for mushrooms for you.
Well?
None to be found.
A pity.
A pity it is. Do you know any more tales? On Svefnii or Velent.

Tales? Don't you bother me! I am a gravedigger. I can dig a grave for you. Not like a common villan one to lay hugging your knees but rather like for the Emperor! Full size, arms outstretched.
But in return...

Ugh.

I brought you some mushrooms.
Good gods in heaven, mushrooms, darling mushrooms!

There. I have helped you. How shall you repay my immense kindness?

Treat me to some brew.

Time to go.
Asveh, brother. How fares it?
Asvedeh. How fares what?
Have you found your, uh, boormonger?

Hush, or you'll be heard! I'd never bother seeking the baromsag myself, but only employ persons such as yourself, spit up on our shores by the sea. Teach you the ropes.
You haven't told no one about this, have you?

Hush, or you'll be heard! I'd never bother seeking the baromsag myself, but only employ persons such as yourself, spit up on our shores by the sea. Teach you the ropes.

No. I do not share secrets. But I have heard you know the ancient myths.
No. I do not share secrets. But I have heard you know the ancient myths.
Our Accur is the one to tell legends. A learned and god-fearing man, especially when he's been drinking khtynka. And like any true scholar, he'll tell you days of stories without stopping.
Maybe I will go see him.
Shall we have a smoke? I have a question...
Why not?

So you tried my mushrooms. Hah! The only true good in our damned place. But know your limits, that's the key. Even I cannot see this tower. And yet here the gods have shown it to you...

Not many. Just a few. Mayhap you've heard of the Order of Vaktaarnatt? If'n enough gallows were built for them, the forest would run clear out of trees!

So you seen that washtub already, eh? Yes, we are. A stupid business. Better to use the wood on coffins!

Oh, Abella, island of dreams! I heard people there spend much on tombs, and so grave diggers prosper. Their shovels ne'er go dull, their hands ne'er tire from the digging, and mushrooms, mushrooms everywhere!
Farewell
*The grave digger is mumbling under his breath. It seems he hasn't noticed you*
Asveh! How do you fare?

Asoveh dendodeh, may he never wake, uh-huh... Have ye spoken with our elder?
Asoveh dendodeh, may he never wake, uh-huh... Have ye spoken with our elder?
With the elder? No.

Then go!
First run unto him. He is our leader and shall examine and consider ye. Shall he decide ye are fit to be here, return to me.
You can find the elder in the communal building, next to the town bell. A long building, ye'll ken it at once.

Right timely, ye are. I be in want of some assistance with fishing.
People keep on coming our way. I reckon this a benefit, for many hands make light work, if I say so. Nary a man here be not in need of nourishment.
As ye are no doubt awares, I hunt and fish for scran, but I only maintain mah pace with difficulty. Your help catching fish would be most welcome.
Ye shall require a proper fishing rod.
Where can I find said fishing rod?

A wooden branch shall be dandy for the greater part of it. Seek ye one out in the forest. Forests grow trees, trees grow branches, and so forests have branches.
We weave rope of Plant Fibers in this realm. Find some and weave it and fix it to the branch.
Believe it or not, in this world we also catch fish in water. Once ye have a fishing rod in hand, go to the shore to begin catching.
Understood.
Ye have any questions?
I have a question about catching fish.

Fish are caught with a fishing rod. Fried on a fire it is really yummy. Once ye have made a rod, find your way to the shore. All ye catch there, be it a wee fish or a whole school, shall be eaten, I assure ye!

I understand.
I have heard it said you possess secret knowledge. That you are able to kindle a fire. Might you teach me?
A fire? Aye, and what be so hard about that? The more firewood, the longer it does burn. Most useful to cook fish or other meat along the way.
I have some fish for you.
I have some fish for you.
Ach, bonnie lad, a sight to behold! Give it here.
Ach, bonnie lass, a sight to behold! Give it here.
Here you go.
Farewell.
Ah, ye are here yet.
Since I am, have you more work for me?

Certainly! Aid with mah hunting I require.
Ye recall that many come hither, a great multitude, all looking to stuff their faces. Our cook prepares scran for them. Do ye ken her, the beauty aye toiling by the cauldron?
Me being a hunter, I pursue fish and beast, but the need has outgrown mah capacity.
Assist me with the wild game. For this, ye will need a weapon, be it ax or sling.
How might I acquire this weapon I need?

This is great wisdom. Well done for asking.
Here, take this sling. With proper skill, the weapon is formidable. Whoever takes a slingshot to the head will not be laughing! Gather some stones lying around for the sling.
Find a boar or something to kill in the woods - but don't go far without a knife.
Get the meat and bring it here.

This is great wisdom. Well done for asking.

Find a boar or something to kill in the woods - but don't go far without a knife.

I have a question regarding hunting.

Hunting brings scran, and scran brings strength and vitality. A good hunt means lots of meat, and eating lots of meat restores your strength for an even better hunt the next time! Now do ye understand mah wisdom?
But a beast is not only meat, for it also possesses hide, bones, horns, tusks... All of these things are most essential. Life without animal skin is impossible, for leather is made from it. Tusks are the makers of superior bows. And bird feathers, as they help the creatures fly – nary an arrow of ours takes flight but with their feathers
Make your way to the forest and track a beast. Aim your face towards the earth and find animal tracks, then follow in them until the beast is in your sight. Then will dawn the moment of truth, and either ye shall kill the beast, or... as the gods do will it.
What beasts inhabit the forest? Which are best to hunt?

As in every place, moose and wild bull, deer and ram, hare and partridge. Wild horses, too. The odd bear, the wolf pack here and there. Ah yes, and the boar.
Yet take nary a moment to seek dragons here, for they be naught.
Which is the most dangerous?

Ye ken it not? The wolf, the bear, and the boar are perilous. Watch that ye be not careless with them. As soon as they hear ye, they shall cast themselves upon ye, intending to devour ye whole.
The moose, the bull, the sheep and ram, and the wild horse are a different matter. They shall attempt to flee. But if driven to despair, they may attack to save their lives.
The hares and partridges, though, are naught but peaceful and shall never harm ye.
That is it.
What about a weapon? How shall I acquire one?
I have some meat for you.
I have some meat for you.

Bonnie lad ye be! Give it to me.
Have ye learned the bases of hunting? Then ye shall continue on your own.

Bonnie lass ye be! Give it to me.

Asveh, brother. How fares it?
Step by step.
Might you grant me some fireleaf for our time together?
Ach, ye wallaper, how dare... ah, it's ye, lad. I shall treat ye to some. Need ye aught besides fireleaf?
Ach, ye wallaper, how dare... ah, it's ye, lass. I shall treat ye to some. Need ye aught besides fireleaf?
I come bearing a question, as always.
Let us hear it.
What is that tower of ships you have?
Might I advise ye to maintain sobriety and avoid swally, and towers of vessels shall trouble ye no more.
Why are so many people hanging here?

It used to be empty and boring, hard to find the path to the village without them. But now ye can aye find it, even at night! Such a happy sight to see when ye seek the way home. And a happy sound, a guiding sound, the way their ropes creak.
I see you are building a ship...
An observant lad, too! Yes, we are building one. We wish to set sail away from this damned place to Abella, an island of blessing and blessedness.
An observant lass, too! Yes, we are building one. We wish to set sail away from this damned place to Abella, an island of blessing and blessedness.

Abella is the island of naught but blessing and blessedness. Each who arrives there finds what he seeks, or so the Accurs say.
Farewell.

Ach, ye wallaper, looking to nab mah fireleaf, eh lad? Begone! Though if ye treat me to some, the gods may reward ye.
So have ye got any fireleaf?

Ach, ye wallaper, looking to nab mah fireleaf, eh lass? Begone! Though if ye treat me to some, the gods may reward ye.

Asoveh Svefnii!

Asoveh dendodah, might 'e never wake. Ye talk wif th'elder?
Go talk wif'im! 'E lead us, y'know. Look in yer eyes, see wotcha doing 'ere. If'n ye from Khoohalday, we hang ye good.
Elder's in the community buildin', right by the ol' ringin' heaven an' hell.
Well, I'll be going, then.
I have spoken with the elder.
I have spoken with the elder.
Well? You spoke wif th'elder?
Asoveh. I have spoken with the elder.
Asoveh. I have spoken with the elder.
Fine, then. I talk wif ye.
I offer help to kind people. Perhaps you need something?

Yer here in a timely fashion, I got a task fer ye!
Bring an axe into the forest. Find a thick oak tree an' cut it down.
Don't ye bring it 'ere, though, saw it into boards right then an' there an' bring the boards here.
Where can I find an ax?

Y'need Ulv, the blacksmif. Bow before 'im, give 'im fireleaf, mayhap 'e give ye an ax.
Learn mah wisdom, now: be friends wif yer neighbors. Good friends. All in this 'ere village 'elp the other. Work together, or we all head straight to the fiery ding dong bell. One man makes no village.
Where can I get a saw?
Yer 'elpless, ain't ye? Get yer skin down to Ulv, I say. Maybe 'e give ye the bear paw ye want.
Got it. I'll go saw some boards.
Got it. I'll go saw some boards.
Any questions?
I understand. Off I go.
I understand. Off I go.
Boards are sawn, and I be done. Too tired to stand. What now?
Boards are sawn, and I be done. Too tired to stand. What now?
Chopper job! Now build a simple box from the boards. Ye can ask Ulv fer nails.
Your tasks are very interesting, I must say. Well, I will get you your box, then.
I understand. I will have it done.
