Of tasks I've had, that was far from easiest. But I have your box.
Of tasks I've had, that was far from easiest. But I have your box.

Hey, square job ye did! Gimme them.
Cut yer fingers off? No? Now ye train an' try to make all sorts o' items. Any questions, come ask.
Well, thank you for the lesson!
Might you grant me some fireleaf during our time together?
Ay, I'm generous today. Let's 'ave a smoke!
What is this tower of ships I see before me?

What tower? Where? I not build any tower, no sir. I build a dive an' dip.
Where'd yer tower come from? Hit yer 'ead somewhere? Go get a khtynka from our cook to get rid o' those harmful thoughts. Good strong stuff straight fra' the steppes.
Who are all those people hanging there?

Not hang, sacrifice for the gods. Gods pleased, they let us free. But no, this is no freedom. This place is no better than a horse's ass. We want freedom. We want Abella, a good place, a happy one.
But the gods, 'em needs more sacrifices.
What are you building here?
Ah, this 'ere be the Baked Bean o' the Sea!
Wow! Uh, what is that?
Tis a dive and dip! For sailin' far. Sailin' to Abella!
A dive and dip? Oh, a ship. Right. I thought it was just a heap of trash.
A dive and dip? Oh, a ship. Right. I thought it was just a heap of trash.
You a shipmaster, then?
No, no, just that such ships do not exist, I swear by Sófaþek.

Wot ye goin' on about? Insultin' me! I been lookin' at scrolls from our Accur, an' this looks jus' like them things in 'is scrolls. An' I swear it by Khoohalday! Ye know what the wisdom o' dive-n-dipmaking is?
Uh, what?

Whatever ye name it, that's 'ow it swim, so say Erthnii, or Kharanhoo.
So I call it by a simple, melodious name: "Hon Hayrata-tan Khere Tangys Essaer Garuy Kharanhoo a Ver."
Which in our native tongue is, "Raven hunter warrior sail o'er the bloody sea 'neath Kharanhoo's cloak, fly to the West."
Yeah, that sound like a right proper name!
But everyone is callin' it "Gavranhavfen," or jus' a "Gavran." An' the gravedigger calls it "the tub." Daft kht'yn, probably jus' gettin' all vines an' trellis.
So why build a ship? You are a Khoor! You live on steppes and wilderness and speak your rhymes and songs, not travel the seas.
For that is the will of our gods! An' the elder. That'll be all I say to that.
Tell me about Abella

Abella is a fine place! I want t' go there, very much.
Steppes stretchin' out t' the horizon, farther than a man can ride in a lifetime. An' grass as tall as a man. Fat herds, sky heavy wif rain, but Amate's rays always shinin'. And Abella's rivers as deep as the 'eavens!
I need to go. Worldly affairs and all.
Tell me about the Baked Bean o' the Sea again.

Why ain't ye listen the last time?
Whatever ye name it, that's 'ow it swim, so say Erthnii, or Kharanhoo.
So I call it by a simple, melodious name: "Hon Hayrata-tan Khere Tangys Essaer Garuy Kharanhoo a Ver."
Which in our native tongue is, "Raven hunter warrior sail o'er the bloody sea 'neath Kharanhoo's cloak, fly to the West."
Yeah, that sound like a right proper name!
But everyone is callin' it "Gavranhavfen," or jus' a "Gavran." An' our gravedigger calls it "the tub." Daft kht'yn, probably jus' gettin' all vines an' trellis.
Ah, another one...
Asoveh Svefnii!
Asoveh. What might I do for you?
I have been cast by the waves onto the shores of this wilderness. Thus I seek the elder. Are you he?

I am. I am called Solev the Listener, and I am the elder here. Yes? *listens* I hear your will.
Now tell me, son, why you are here, and who you are. From whence have the gods brought you? Hold nothing back, for the gods see all, tell all...
I must know all about you. And so must the gods. Speak, for I listen, and determine what sort of vegetable you be.

I am. I am called Solev the Listener, and I am the elder here. Yes? *listens* I hear your will.
Now tell me, daughter, why you are here, and who you are. From whence have the gods brought you? Hold nothing back, for the gods see all, tell all...
I must know all about you. And so must the gods. Speak, for I listen, and determine what sort of vegetable you be.
Vegetable? We are humans, or are you not aware?
So I see, two arms, two legs, even a head on your shoulders. And yet I see no seal, no mark. Which of the gods do you follow?
So I see, two arms, two legs, even a head on your shoulders. And yet I see no seal, no mark. Which of the gods do you follow?
Svefnii, the Sleeper. May he never wake.
May he never wake, may his sleep be eternal, may he reside in the cold darkness. Yes? *listens to the gods*
I say so. And I was cast upon your shores by the waves.
Thus it is.
Who I am, who I was, I remember nothing more of that.
Who I am, who I was, I remember nothing more of that.
That, I believe. Yes? *listens*
I only recall that I dreamed of arriving at Abella.
I only recall that I dreamed of arriving at Abella.

Yes, yes.
Does this all seem strange to you? Indeed, when I first came to these shores, I was likewise astonished. Be not astounded, nor hold unneeded thoughts in your mind, or you will become like our Gravedigger.
We are all here in the will of the gods, as are all! Yes?
Indeed, indeed.
Nobody in these parts wants to talk to me. Say I might be Gloomdung.

Indeed, they are right to not wish to. The waves bring all sorts to our cursed shores. Perhaps you are human, or mayhap you are but a pretender. Or even a bastard heretic. For so some prove themselves to be. Yes, yes.
We always have a free rope for such invaders. Yes? *listening* Yes, and a sharp stake, of course.
Bear no ill will towards the people of this village. They have endured much. Now, they shall speak with you.
Thank you. Farewell.

Wait. Here is the secret prayer, which can return you to your home from any place. Yes? Yes, yes.
Then, do not run away far. Bind a place in the house and come back to me.
Once again, thank you. Asvedeh, Elder.
*When he sees you, the elder cocks his head, listening from his left ear*
Shall I share some fireleaf with you, Elder?
Why should it not be so? Share, as you are so generous. You come bearing a question, I see. Speak it.
Why should it not be so? Share, as you are so generous. You come bearing a question, I see. Speak it.
Of a surety, I do. Why have you covered the field with idols?

Idols? Idols... Yes, that I may answer. For the gods. Those, who were before us placed them, and so we, too, have placed them here.
For we must appease the gods, so that they shall better hear us and shall release hence. Hitherto, however, their will has been... no!
Have you trouble hearing, Elder? You often ask me to repeat myself.

Me? Trouble hearing? No. I...
Hmm, why are you here? Go! I must speak with the gods. They... they require an offering, and offering...
Uh, yes, I'll be going...
What is this tower of ships I see before me?
I knew you were the chosen of the gods! No, I see nothing. I am but an ordinary man, and thus I may live awhile more.
I knew you were the chosen of the gods! No, I see nothing. I am but an ordinary man, and thus I may live awhile more.
Why are so many hanging here?

So you have taken notice. Observant. The gods value that trait. What's that? Yes, yes. Those hanging here are those we have come to call the heretics. Those of the mysterious Holza's fog, who came to this island seeking to do only Svefnii knows what to us all.

So you have taken notice. Observant. The gods value that trait. What's that? Yes, yes. Those hanging here are those we have come to call the heretics. Those of the mysterious Holza's fog, who came to this island seeking to do only Svefnii knows what to us all.
Only Svefnii knows what?

They named our gods "enemies of the human race" and called for our idols to be smashed and burned. They would not recognize our god, Svefnii. And so, we... We hung them out to dry in the fiery eyes of Amate, that their evil thoughts may be erased, and so they became pleasing to the gods.
Among their number were found some warrior priests skilled with weaponry, and so we had to erect walls around the village. But that was all in the past, and the present demands that we act for the glory of the gods and for our salvation.
One of the deeds so required was sacrifice... What's that?
The hammer of Svefnii. I hear it! Its roar calls me...
I see you are building a ship...
Indeed we are. And its completion does require a bloody sacrifice!
Tell me what this place is.
It is called the Village. *listens* What's that?
Just "the village"?

Dare not to laugh, dear one. Yes, "the Village."
We have named our village many times, but those names no one can now recall, for the gods do not will it.
The Village is located on an island named Idirverden. Some, however, call it Illa-sogskelle, and others call it – or called it, rather – "Purgatory," mean that whatever it will.
Our grave digger, however, has quite a simple name for it when he's drunk. And then our carpenter call it by those funny rhymes of his.
I see.
Please tell me where I can find...
the Hunter
That is known. The Hunter is always along the shore, under the trees there.
the Accur
That is known. Our Accur is always by the bell.
the Blacksmith
In the blacksmith's shop of course. Where else?
the Carpenter
Search for him by the ship, for it is there that he labors.
the Farmer
He hangs about the kitchen, the villain. Seeking something from the cook, it seems. Yes, yes...
the Cook
Follow the scent of food to find the enchantress who makes it for us. In the kitchen.
the Gravedigger
Search the field of idols and you will likely find him.
Tell me about Abella

O Abella, magical island where wishes are granted! A place of peace and order, a place where elders are respected. Yes, yes... the gods are there respected as well, and receive abundant offerings from the people. And fireleaf there is never stolen!
I'll be going.
How looks your fireleaf situation, Elder?
Some bastard has stolen my fireleaf pouch! Who did it? Have you heard or seen anything which might reveal him to you?
Some bastard has stolen my fireleaf pouch! Who did it? Have you heard or seen anything which might reveal him to you?
No, I know nothing.
No, I know nothing.
Farewell.
*The cook looks at you curiously, but without neglecting her cooking work*
Asveh, khanir!
Asvedeh. Beautiful, huh... Who taught ye our greetin'?
No one. My heart saw you, and told me what to say!
And di' this heart o' yers tell ye the need t' speak wif th'elder first?
No. Why?
Ye have t'speak wif 'im first. All do it that way, an' ye go speak wif 'im, too. Then I speak wif ye, af'er th'elder 'as a look at ye.
Then I shall be off.
Seriously, though. How else would I know?
Asveh Svefnii!

<font:Open Sans Italic:20>A pickerel shines in the water, jumps into the sunset. Amate welcomes the pickerel, an' then it dives into the night ocean. The pickerel thought she'd leapt free of a strong bone hook, an' now...
Had she?
Who?
The pickerel.
Pickerel? You spoken wif our elder yet or no?
Pickerel? You spoken wif our elder yet or no?
Yes.
Good. Wot ye be needin' fra me?
I am looking for food.
No, we have not spoken yet.
Then go an' speak.

Look, this be the kitchen. Every village 'as one.
'Ere we make food. Most important resource of 'em all. Ye watch yer food be good, else ye learn yer skills all slow, and yer food be fer naught but takin' up space. So if'n ye want t'learn faster, eat!
Teach me how to make food, too.

Ye go an' 'unt a beast, or grab some eggs from the 'enhouse, an' don't ye eat 'em right away, ye go an' bring 'em 'ere. Or start a fire right in the forest an' cook 'em that way. Ye can ask the Hunter about the fire, but it be simple. Take sticks, add fire.
If ye find no game an' the chickens ain't laid, catch some bugs from out under yer feet, or pull up some roots. Roots, now they ain't 'alf bad. Ye can also pick apples, berries, or mushrooms.
What need have we of this kitchen when we may cook fish and meat over the fire?

Ye cannot make true good, abundant food o'er a fire out in the woods. We not talk 'bout no roots an' berries now.
To really fill up yer belly, needin' no more fer three days, findin' naught but success, yer food must be smartly cooked wif many prepared ingredients. Like my food. So ye need to cook this food in the kitchen.
Where do I get these ingredients?

As I say, many ways. Count 'em: Huntin'. Fishin'. Growin' fruits an' vegetables. 'Shrooms and berries from the forest, an' wild apples.
Pick whiche'er ye like.
Let us say I eat your food. Will I go hungry soon?
Let us say I eat your food. Will I go hungry soon?
Depends on yer activities, stranger. If ye sit wif yer pipe, long time before ye need to eat again. But if ye work the sweat o' yer brow all day, though, in honor o' the Sleeper, ye need more soon.
Depends on yer activities, stranger. If ye sit wif yer pipe, long time before ye need to eat again. But if ye work the sweat o' yer brow all day, though, in honor o' the Sleeper, ye need more soon.
I see, O great beauty. Now I shall be safe, for you have safeguarded my life!
I see. Now I shall be safe, for you have safeguarded my life!
Got it. Thank you for the lesson.
<font:Open Sans Italic:20>Asveh Kalle, Asveh Holza.
Might you grant me some fireleaf for our time together?

Hunger drive ye mad, eh? I be a decent woman, no fireleaf on me!
Though... if ye have some, I have a smoke wif ye! Would na say no t'such a fine man.

Hunger drive ye mad, eh? I be a decent woman, no fireleaf on me!
Though... if ye have some, I have a smoke wif ye!
Hmm. Well, I have a little. Here you go, "decent woman."
Well, wot ye waitin' fer? Ye 'ave somethin' else ye wanna treat me too, come on, no need bein' shy.
Well, ye need somethin' else?
Would that I could, but I am too shy. How about you answer a question instead?
I do have a question for you.
Yes?
What is this tower of ships I see?
Tower o' ships? Wot ye be on about? Many strange things ye might see on this island, true.
Tower o' ships? Wot ye be on about? Many strange things ye might see on this island, true.
Why are so many people hanging here?

Not people. Reprobates, 'eretics. Our elder said to 'ang 'em, saw 'em fer wot they were at first glance. I believe 'im. After all, none of 'em saw my children, but they're 'ere, cryin', callin' out t'me, and I 'ear 'em.
Do you 'ear 'em?
I hear something, surely. Like the wind howling, crying.
I see you are building a ship...
Fer sure ya, we build. My children call to me. They wait on Abella. We finish buildin' and sail there, an' I find 'em.
Tell me, please, why is your elder so...
Dropped as a baby? 'Tis all the power, gone to 'is 'ead, poor thing. Heehee.
Uh, well, I see. Thank you.
I be kiddin'! Where you goin'? The elder, no real authority of 'is own. It all be Them.
I be kiddin'! Where you goin'? The elder, no real authority of 'is own. It all be Them.
Them?

The gods. He 'ears 'em. They whisper to 'im wot to do. Places 'round 'ere, close to the gods, sometimes I 'ear 'em, too.
They whisper t' me o' me children, as if they be alive. And waitin' fer me. Their Sparks shine fer me, in the darkness.
<font:Open Sans Italic:20>Asveh Holza... Asveh Kalle...
What... wait. Wait! Hey!

Asveh Kalle...
Kallente be our good mother. Our patroness. She watches o'er our 'arvest, makin' it abundant an' timely. Protectin' it from 'ail an' frost.
She keeps our 'earth, 'olding its fire so it don't go out. An' keepin' the fire betwixt man an' woman from goin' out, too. Bringin' forth many children... children...
'Ave ye seen my children? They're cryin', I can 'ear 'em...

Asveh Kalle...
Kallente be our good mother. Our patroness. She watches o'er our 'arvest, makin' it abundant an' timely. Protectin' it from 'ail an' frost.
She keeps our 'earth, 'olding its fire so it don't go out. An' keepin' the fire betwixt man an' woman from goin' out, too. Bringin' forth many children... children...
'Ave ye seen my children? They're cryin', I can 'ear 'em...
No, I have not. My regrets. I'll be going.
No, I have not. My regrets. I'll be going.
Tell me about Abella
The Apple Land, 'tis free o' grief, an' soon we all go there.
Save me, O beauty, for my insides are roiling. I must eat!
Always 'ungry, always more...
Thank you! I'll be going now.
Thank you! I'll be going now.
I die, O beautiful cook. Of hunger. If only I had a little porridge...
Can ye not manage, dear? It's time for you to learn how to get food for yourself. Go to the hunter, he will teach you. Or collect some roots if ye really need.
Can ye not manage, dear? It's time for you to learn how to get food for yourself. Go to the hunter, he will teach you. Or collect some roots if ye really need.
Mayhap I can help you with something?
Huh? Have ye seen my children? Can ye 'ear 'em? They be cryin'! Asveh Kalle...
Huh? Have ye seen my children? Can ye 'ear 'em? They be cryin'! Asveh Kalle...
Where must I look for them?
<font:Open Sans Italic:20>Asveh Kalle... Asveh Holza...
I'll be going...
*You hear the cook whispering, her food completely forgotten*
Asveh, O beautiful one!
A... sveh...
Do you require anything? Water delivered or the roof fixed, perhaps? I must find something to do with my young man's strength!
Do you require anything? Water delivered or the roof fixed, perhaps?
<font:Open Sans Italic:20>Asveh Holza... Asveh Kalle... Asveh Jomfru...

<font:Open Sans Italic:20>Tears drop fra Kalle's face, the 'earth 'as gone out...
blood boils on the coals. One of us is there,
sitting on the grave watchin' the sunset...
In the quite, abandoned 'ome abides a fatal silence.

<font:Open Sans Italic:20>The scarlet thread in Holza's 'and will turn into a black snake... This snake in turn becomes a blade, which takes the Joker's life... And out his Spark shall go, as red rain falls upon the Lungs...
Asveh Holza... Asveh Kalle... Asveh Jomfru... Asveh Johdenandhe.
I'm sorry, O lovely one. Perhaps I'll go.
I'm sorry. Perhaps I'll go.
*Lodur sits, dangling his legs*
There you are, little one! What are you doing here alone?
Then give it here. Pickerel! Haha!
What are you doing here alone?

If we take a kudritt and wrap it in a ribbon... Nah.
These people in the village, have they taught you everything? Yes, you have strong legs and arms, but are you prepared?

If we take a kudritt and wrap it in a ribbon... Nah.
These people in the village, have they taught you everything? Yes, you have strong legs and arms, but are you prepared?
What, in your observation, must I be prepared for?
What, in your observation, must I be prepared for?

My sister, Mara. Have you met her? Well, she has met you. She watches the new people, for she does not understand you.
She is like unto a little girl. Plays a fear. She fears rustles in the night. She fears the cries of owls. 'Tis funny.
Just yesterday I heard the wolves hear howling. Also funny! Do you know hunger? We do. We know it well. And so do the wolves, and the mosquitoes. Do they bite you?

My sister, Mara. Have you met her? Well, she has met you. She watches the new people, for she does not understand you.
She is like unto a little girl, afraid. She fears rustles in the night. She fears the cries of owls. 'Tis funny.
Just yesterdayI heard the wolves hear howling. Also funny! Do you know hunger? We do. We know it well. And so do the wolves, and the mosquitoes. Are they biting?

What, then? Can you not see? We are the frightened children, unable to care for ourselves, nowhere to hide from the foul weather, from the night horrors – and any man or beast we meet could send us to the grave.
But if you are truly ready, you can help us. You can save us.

What, then? Can you not see? We are the frightened children, unable to care for ourselves, nowhere to hide from the foul weather, from the night horrors – and any man or beast we meet could send us to the grave.
But if you are truly ready, you can help us. You can save us.
I do not understand. You wish me to take you to the village, to your mother?
No! We cannot enter the village! The blacksmith once banished us. Mad, he wanted to kill us all!
Do you need some kind of help?
*Lodur pops his eyes and sticks out his tongue*
Build us a shelter! Or we will all... die here. Look...
Gods be good! Where did you acquire gold?
We have more. Lots more. How about it?
I have heard tell that structures here do not last long.
I have heard tell that structures here do not last long.
We only need it for a short time. Can you do it?
Yes. You shall have your shelter.

No one ever sails away from here. But you are a different matter altogether. Though...
How is our shelter going?
Not ready yet. Soon.
No need to hurry. Mara's not about to freeze to death or anything.
It is done.
Hah, you did it!
Hah, you did it!
Where is my reward?
Your real reward is Abella. You may go there now.
How do I get there?
The boat man will take you. Mara asked him to, but you'll still need to give him payment.
The boat man will take you. Mara asked him to, but you'll still need to give him payment.
Who is this boatman?
What do you care? He'll take you. For payment. One way only.
Alright.
*Lodur gazes at you thoughtfully*
Is Mara your sister?
Aye. She is stupid, and always cold. The blacksmith nigh killed her when we desired to live with them all.
Blacksmiths do not, as a rule, kill children.

He is mad, I say. But no matter.
Mara has a scythe, and we will kill him ourselves later. Then I will play A Spark Goes Out over his corpse, haha!
Strange boy.
*Mara gazes at the heavens, taking no notice of you*
There you are.
There you are! We were waiting for you. This place is not exactly warm.
What are you doing out here alone? Your mother is looking for you.
We're playing! And we're not alone... by the way, we have a job for you. Did Lodur tell you already? Go ask him!
How about instead I take you back to the village, to your mother?

You don't know our mother. And you definitely can't take us to her!
We're allowed to play anywhere on the island. Or even with the island. Or with you. Or with the elder. With anyone and anywhere we want!
Goodbye, child.
Did you help Lodur?
Did you help Lodur?
Not yet.
Why?
I built you a hut.
I built you a hut.
You did it!
You did it!
And my reward?
Your real reward is Abella. You may go there now.
That's your reward. We've chosen you.
*Mara gazes through you*
Is Lodur your brother?
No, but you should help him.
No, but you should help him.
*Assel sizes you up*
Asoveh Svefnii!
Asveh. What do you need?
Well, I...

Wait. First go talk to the elder. He is our leader. He will examine you, determine whether you are a good person or Gloomdung. Shall he grant you his blessing to be here, I will talk with you.
You shall find the elder in the long building nearby.
We have already spoken.
Have you spoken with the elder?
Have you spoken with the elder?

Then go.
He is our leader and shall examine and consider you. Shall he decide you are fit to be here, return to me.

Then go.
He is our leader and shall examine and consider you. Shall he decide you are fit to be here, return to me.
It is good that you have spoken. Now I shall talk with you. And I do love to talk.
It is good that you have spoken. Now I shall talk with you. And I do love to talk.
I have a practical question.

You may ask it later.
First, you must clean the chicken coop, for that will please the gods! The coop's cages are full of droppings, and the birds perish before they even reach the kitchen cauldron, ceasing to produce eggs to sustain me for the glory of the gods.
Therefore hearken to this quest: You must clean the chicken coop in the village and collect the eggs. The chickens must not perish from the dung and so you must complete the cleaning before more hatch.
Proceed!

You may ask it later.
First, you must clean the chicken coop, for that will please the gods! The coop's cages are full of droppings, and the birds perish before they even reach the kitchen cauldron, ceasing to produce eggs to sustain me for the glory of the gods.
Therefore hearken to this quest: You must clean the chicken coop in the village and collect the eggs. The chickens must not perish from the dung and so you must complete the cleaning before more hatch.
Proceed!
I understand. It shall be done!
Understood. It shall be done!
You have returned with haste. Have you cleaned the coops?
You have returned with haste. Have you cleaned the coops?
I have cleaned all the droppings that I found.
I have cleaned all the droppings that I found.
And have you brought this old man some eggs?
And have you brought this old man some eggs?
Here is one egg for you.
One? What?
That is all they laid...

My child, the time has come for me to plant yet another grain of wisdom into your unreasoned mind.
Since ancient times there have existed invisible spiritual laws, laws not established by us. Every decent person must respect such laws or receive all sorts of terrible troubles upon their head.
Liars and perjurers, deceivers and murderers, robbers and other harmers of men and women violate these invisible laws.
So why do you, dear one, attempt to cheat this humble servant of the gods? For this your unforgivable act, you shall receive inescapable and terrible punishment.

The judgment for your transgression shall be deadly. In any settlement, however, you must be first judged by the laws of men, not yet the laws of the gods.
Therefore I shall bring you to the elder and tell him all, and they shall stone you and hang you.
Stop! Gloom got to me! Forgive me and I shall give you the eggs.

That is not sufficient.
But let it be so. I shall give you the rare opportunity to restore your name.
Approach the idol, fall prostrate before him, and cry out to the Sleeper and to the other gods until your conscience clears.
And give me back those eggs.
I understand. I will do as you say.
I understand. I will do as you say.
Tell me, O wise one, what is happening here?
Share some fireleaf with me, and I shall.
Of course I will share.
Then I am listening.
What is that tower of ships you have?
We do all for the will of our gods! They see all, know all, watch all, and direct us all.
And why are all those people hanging?

They are heretics and degenerates, and as such they are hung to dry before the eyes of Amate! Monsters who brought in themselves evil unto this island, marked for judgment by the gods. We and the elder found them out in good time, and so we made our pleasing offering to Amate, presenting them before her eyes.
I see you are building a ship...
Indeed! We must set sell from this island to that of Abella as soon as the gods so bless us.
Well, Father, I shall take my leave.
I don't have any.
I shall go now.
I shall go now.
What is your question for me?
I was struck by a wooden plank recently. To whom shall I go?

You are right to consult with me, for I work much with wood.
And therefore I say to you that first of all, you must please the gods. You shall need an ax and a saw.
You may take this ax, but you shall not lose it or dull its edge! You will ask the saw at our shipbuilder Yermyk.
Take it into the forest, select a suitable tree, and bring it down. When you cut down, drag the log exactly to the idol. Then go to the field. Make your cries to the Sleeper,or to whomever you pray there, place the idol in the earth.
The field of idols is located outside of the village, to the north.

You are right to consult with me, for I work much with wood.
And therefore I say to you that first of all, you must please the gods. You shall need an ax and a saw.
You may take this ax, but you shall not lose it or dull its edge! You will ask the saw at our shipbuilder Yermyk.
Take it into the forest, select a suitable tree, and bring it down. When you cut down, drag the log exactly to the idol. Then go to the field. Make your cries to the Sleeper,or to whomever you pray there, place the idol in the earth.
The field of idols is located outside of the village, to the north.
I do not understand, alas. Please explain it to me again.
I do not understand, alas. Please explain it to me again.

Then hearken to me yet again.
Select the place you intend to raise the idol. Place your construction area for it on the ground, and a sign will appear. Be not afraid of this magic, for it is by the will of the gods.
Then, cut down a tree. Your saw shall turn the tree into a log. Place this log into your unfinished construction area marked by the sign, and it is finished.
Just be sure you know to whom this idol shall be ahead of time.
I have placed the idol.
I have placed the idol.
Worthy of commendation. A young man is always better off when god-fearing and obedient. Yet instead of this empty praise, here – receive from me this gift.
Worthy of commendation. A young woman is always better off when god-fearing and obedient. Yet instead of this empty praise, here – receive from me this gift.
Thank you for your generosity.
Indeed.
*Assell gazes at you with a drunken stare*
Tell me about our world...

Our world since ancient times has been called Sparksvaard.
And it grows like an apple on a branch of the great World Tree. But it is not alone, for it sits among the worlds of our gods. As we mortal humans build ourselves houses, so the gods did in ancient days resolve that they needed worlds of their own.
And they made it so.
Do you say so?

Since that time, Svefnii the Sleeper has resided in the fiery forges of Risterverden, chained to the World Tree by his own kin.
Gloom the Horny wanders his halls in Izenlen.
Holza, Kallente, Amate, and Velent are neighbors to Gloom in Izenlen, where their halls likewise reside, and Gloom "drops by" at times, of course, hee hee.
I do not blame him.
You don't say!

Hold on, listen still!
Terskel the One-Armed, along with his ice army, keeps eternal vigil on the walls of Terrskellen, built around the flaming Risterverden.
Johdenandhe and Jomfrutotte share the frozen plains of Smertverden. But the younger sister, Jomfru, expends more of her time in our world...

Sófaþek-king, bringing all to exhaustion by his wisdom, was banished by the maidens of Day and Night from Izenlen, and now resides on its threshold, pestering all who pass by with questions that have no answers, and generously sharing his weighty wisdom.
Indeed, his wisdom is so heavy that any who receives but a tiny portion of it falls forthwith to Johde and Smertverden...
This was revealed to me after few good swallows of khtynka.
Tell me of our gods.
Of which of them do you wish to hear?
Of all of them, but in summary

Both old and young know of our gods. Rarely do such as you creep onto our shores... well, fair enough. Hear then the legends of old.
Our world is ruled by cunning, spiteful gods, among them the sun Amate, the hurried Velent Night, the trickster Gloom, and mistress of time Holza the Spinstress, and the sisters Jomfru and Johde, mistresses of our deaths. The beauty Kallente, helper of all the earth, is among them, as well, along with the craftsman Aori and the wiseman Sófaþek-king.
It is noted that these gods exercise active influence. Furthermore, our greatest god is bewitched, imprisoned in the depths of the world, and he is called Svefnii by the Slavards, or commonly the Sleeper. May he sleep soundly forever, and may his wrath pass from us.
So there you are. Relations between mortals and the gods are maintained by the lowly Accurs, including myself. Turn to me if you need anything in this regard.
If you feel you have offended the gods, come to me with all haste, and bring a worthy sacrifice. I, as it is written, shall... pass it on.
Svefnii the Sleeper

Hear me, then.
The highest of the gods of our world is the Sleeper. The Slavards call him Svefnibrann, which being interpreted is the Sleeping Fire. Or, just Svefnii, the Sleeper. Called Akneh-Hootga or Akneh by the Khoors, but we, the Gottlungs, possess the true knowledge and therefore call him the Sleeper.
Other names for him include the Hammerer, the Napping One and the Slumberer, the Hammerheaded, the Treeshaker, the Master, and the Hammer Master. Some blasphemers dare call him the Snorer, but for that they shall doubtless pay, for the Sleeper's wrath and vengeance is terrible indeed.
Huh. Yes.

Stern is the Sleeper, most severe!
He slumbers now in the depths of our world, his unquenchable fury smoldering within him. He must not awaken from that sleep, or he shall rise to his full immensity and rend the earth, filling it with fire! Then Svefnii shall strike down the World Tree, destroying both worlds and heavens, and time itself shall cease.
And the last battle shall come, where all the gods shall fall before the wrath of Svefnii in Godernblodbad!
Gordebod... Gordonblee... what is it? It sounds terrible!

GODERNBLODBAD!
It is the Godmassacre, the final battle, wherein the Sleeper, so the scriptures say, shall ruin all of the gods, and the worlds shall be reduced to dust and engulfed in flame!
And mortals shall burn as fuel for his furnace.
I am sorry I asked, and my brow sweats from the mere prospect!
I am sorry I asked, and my brow sweats from the mere prospect!

Be not overly much occupied by fear.
For to prevent the Sleeper from awakening, we, the Accurs, are here in the world, as it is written. The sweat on our brows runs red from the toil of our labor in unceasing rituals. We strengthen the earth with all of our might!
For this strengthening and this labor... meals of meat and eggs really are best, on a daily basis, if possible.
And it is advisable to wash it down with khtynka, for a certainty.
And what if... what if I make it myself?

Make an offering?
You require true understanding for that!
If you wish to offer khtynka or fresh meat, bring it hither to me. I may... speed your sacrifice on its way through the earth, to the underworld.
On your own, it shall be very hard, very hard labour indeed. The Sleeper requires the sacrifice of blood and sweet from ordinary mortals, so the scriptures say.
Should you cultivate the land or raise a building, the sweat of your brow is your sacrifice. And should you fight a battle, your offering is the blood you shed.
Thank you for teaching me.
Aori Goldenhanded

Aori is the Master, who at the command of the ancient gods created the silver braces of our world of Sparksvaard and made sure the heavenly dome dividing the worlds of Elgverden from the universe outside, the world of the Creator. He was defeated in the Godmassacre and disappeared into the Outer Light.
We do not pray to him, as a rule, and yet if you have a great desire, you may bring me a boar, and I shall express your wishes to him, as it is written.
Gloom the Jester

Call also the Jester, the Slacker, the Aspid, the Horny One, the Thief, and called Khoohalday by the Khoors.
He received none of the inner flame, when the Ereborns blinded him. But Svefnii himself gave a piece of this flame to Gloom, torn from his very self, as it is written.
Gloom is crafty and cunning! It was he who persuaded his sister, Alglemy, to lie with Svefnii the Sleeper and to implant in him the idea of mutiny against the Ereborns. And Svefnii the Sleeper lay with her indeed.
So the...

This living sword, Gloom stole from the Wisest Ones. It is called Vallum Tussenrost, for this sword was the only way to defeat a Wise Man.
But Gloom could not hold it, for Gloom is known for his cunning, not his strength. And the Sleeper took up the sword.
But the...

If not for Gloom, there would have been no Godmassacre, so I understand. So be sure to appease him with abundant offerings, for Gloom is indeed mischievous and vindictive.
Thus it happened. And the battle began, among the very gods! The heavens were engulfed in flame!
Their arms, and legs, and other assorted parts rained down upon mortals, and their blood with it, filling the worlds with fire!
It was the Godmassacre...
Pause the nightmare story for a moment. What was that about Alglemy?
Huh?
Svefnii lay with this Alglemy. And?

Ah, I see what you are getting at.
So the Sleeper lay with Alglemy at length and with great passion, as a strong warrior. The heavens and the earth trembled at their love. For Alglemy's passion was great, and full of love. And the Sleeper never grew tired!
Whoa.

And so they loved, and loved long.
But she betrayed the Sleeper, plunging the knife of her womanly treachery into his back. And his blood fell upon the earth, and seized the world in flame. People, cities, countries burned!
Oof.
And so Gloom...
Wait, what happened with Alglemy and the Sleeper?

You and your Alglemy...
She was a traitor! She betrayed our Svefnii, as it is written. And the only conversation one may have with a traitor is...
A very short one?

Indeed!
Svefnii stood on one leg, so the scriptures say, and pulled the other.
And thus her story ended.
And...
And her blood did rain upon the earth, engulfing it in fire, and all did come to burning, yes, I guessed as much.
Holza the Spinstress

Holza the Spinstress, Old Holza, is the Mother of Time and the Mistress of Fate. She is the patroness of time.
She weaves her Eternal Tapestry of Fate, working in all that must happen to us unworthy mortals, and mayhap even all that may happen to the gods themselves. None have ever looked upon her face, not even the gods, yet they call her the Old, perhaps for her great wisdom, or perhaps she is indeed as old as the pants I wear.
The gods love not Holza for her wisdom. Gloom the Horny is especially contrary to her.
When you do wish to appease the Mother of Time, take a strong basket and place therein two or three pounds of meat, dried or cooked fish, a loaf of bread wrapped in a clean rag, a flask or two of khtynka – two is better, yes. And place there also a new pair of pants.
Float all of this down the river. Only give me warning first, according to the scriptures, when you have deemed it right to give an offering to Holza. I shall... ensure your sacrifice reaches its destination.
Kallente

Kallente is the goddess of beauty, motherhood, and fertility. She is patroness of the hearth and home, and thus of the lovers' embrace.
Were you a girl of succulence, I would tell you how to serve Kallente. Ahem.
Go ahead and ask Karegast. He is an expert on serving Kallente, hah!
Amate-Maksha, the Sunmaiden

The Sunmaiden, called Amate by us, Amate-Maksha by the Slavards, and Amat'i by the Khoors.
She is eternally young and unspeakably beautiful, the Fiery-rayed, giving us fire and light.
Know that the beauty of any woman is but a reflection of the countenance of the Sunmaiden. The marks of her patronage are blond or white hair.

Amate the Sun and Velent the Hasty are sisters. And so the two of them are often called "the Sisters." Our high priests say the Sisters meet during times of eclipse and determine matters of life and death for their chosen people, those with the mark of the Sleeper, their brother, making such determinations without consideration of the Sleeper's will. So the wisest Accurs have written upon the Tablets of Risterverden.
Amate the Sun has no interest in the affairs of mortals, and barely any interest in the affairs of the gods. Only her own interests concern her.
Her world is Izenlen.
Velent-Ellyanae

Velent-Ellyanae, which is interpreted Velent the Hasty. Called Velent the Dark, Velent-An-Maksha, and Mother Night by the Slavards and Kharanhoo by the Khoors.
Her scythe is sharp and silver and cuts short our lives in the night.
She is patroness of all under the shadow of her dark cloak. Her time is night, the time of dark deeds.
She is Amate's twin sister, but of the darkness, not the light.
Dark brown or black hair is the mark of Velent's patronage.
Her world is Izenlen.
Terskel and the Three

Terskel is the one-armed warrior who keeps eternal vigil over the walls of Terrskellen, the ring world, the wall world barring access to the world of the Sleeper, Risterverden.
It is a cold, icy world, isolating the fiery Risterverden from the other worlds.
"In the Godmassacre, Terskel blew a great alarm on his horn Rivelim, signaling Aori to smash the silver brace of the heavenly sphere. Terskel's other arm, severed by the Ereborns, still grasps the bellowing horn Rivelim and ever floats throughout space, circling the world of humanity. As the elders will tell you, that horn still sounds forth. Sometimes, when the night is especially dark and quiet, you can hear it."
Along with Terskel, eternal vigil on the wall is kept by the Three Nameless Ice Knezi. There are more Knezi, twelve in total.
Johdenandhe, the Dead Maiden

The Maiden of the Red Scythe, the Cold One, the Iceeyed, called Amghooy by the Khoors and Lei by the northerners
She is the goddess of death! Her world, Smertverden, lies between the world of men, Sparksvaard, and the world of the Sleeper, Risterverden.
The Slavards say that all who die of old age and all who lose their sword or shame themselves on the field of battle are sent to the bed of Johdenandhe. There, she extinguishes their Spark once and for all with her "embrace of love." When Johdenandhe embraces something, nothing remains.
But true warriors – godlike heroes inflamed with fury who give their lives in battle – fly through the world of the Iceeyed, blazing holes through her ensnaring bedsheets.
Sheesh!

Beyond lies the Sleeper's Forge, and then his Hammer and his Anvil, awaiting all true heroes. For the Sleeping God is forging the Sparks of the dead together into a great blade of Vengeance.
But not all are worthy of this, and so not all make it through the Forge.
Johde regularly manifests herself in the world of humans, summoning to herself three of the Twelve Nameless Ice Knezi – three of which keep vigil on the walls of Terskellen, and nine of which guard the breach in the heavenly dome. She summons them, for she knows their names, and to know their names is to have authority over them. When she does this, winter comes to Sparksvaard.
It is believed that should Johde call all of the Ice Knezi at once, eternal winter and the kingdom of death will dawn in the world of humans!
We Gottlungs simply offer her lambs, and that is well and good. Especially when the lambs are young and well fed. Offering them up as a burnt offering, with khtynka, that pleases us Accurs greatly! And to please the Accurs is to please Johde.
But she does greatly adore freshly shed blood.
Jomfrutotte

The Iceeyed's younger sister.
The messenger of her older sister, Death, she personally comes to collect the Sparks of the dead. She is always among us!
She is curious, like unto all of our gods, and may watch you, especially in acts of battle or love. It is known. She takes interest in mortal affairs.
This is why our maidens who are especially shy devise implements of modesty before the various entertainments of love. Some may hide their face with a handkerchief while upon the bed, while others fall prostrate upon it and offer prayers to Kallente, that she may hinder Jomfru and send them a child, so the scriptures say.
Jodenande and Jomfrutotte are often confused for one another, and indeed the distinction between them touches us little, but the older survives on human Sparks, and the younger on pain and the thirst for survival that ignites within us as we approach death.
The Younger Sister brings our Sparks to the Older Sister, as one might bring a gift of a basket of mushrooms.
Sófaþek-king

The warrior of the Throne of Wisdom, he is the god of knowledge and wise council, which he possesses in abundance. These he shares abundantly with all, whether they stand in need of it or no.
He reclines on his soft bench with its soft back – and his eyes, burned out in Godernblodbad, see through the whole realm of existence.
To us Accurs he grants his wisdom without ceasing, so whene'er you require counsel, do not hesitate to come. And forget not to bring a lamb.
Do you know any legends?
I know a multitude of legends! But my throat is overly dry to tell them.
Shall I bring you some khtynka?

Your intellect impresses. Bring me some, and I shall quench my thirst and tell you however much you desire.
You shall never hear such wisdom elsewhere, so hurry.
I shall bring the brew.
I have khtynka for you. Shall we drink?

Give it here.
'Tis my drink, not yours. But I shall drink to your health. To our gods! *gulp*
I have heard that the gods desire a diversity of things.

Oh, woe is me! Wherefore have you removed your favor from me, O gods?
I am smitten by fate, as a cow pie by a boot...
Huh?
Oh gods, oh gods! Why?
Has something happened?
Who is here?
It is I, as before.

Aha! Here is a good one who shall help me perform an act for the glory of the gods! The messenger of the gods who shall help me fulfill what Gloom has predetermined for me this day!
Hearken, O messenger. *he whispers in your ear*
Calm yourself, Father. She is imagining her children again, with much mention of Johde...

Johde, you say? Then the sacrifice to Kallente must needs wait. And Khoytu-khanir also possesses a scythe, like unto that of Jode – though it be not yet red.
Gloom we shall delight instead!
For that end, you must... *he whispers in your ear*
What? Pinch fireleaf from the elder? What has gotten into you, Father?

Hush now, lower your voice. Yes, his fireleaf, that shall please Gloom.
Proceed with all stealth and caution into the community house and find therein a chest. Take the fireleaf from that same chest and bring it to me, to the glory of the gods.
You shall often have need of this skill in Abella, moving about quietly and sharing everything, for you shall have good neighbors there. And Gloom wills that we live with our neighbors in peace and shared prosperity! So learn the way, then, while I still live, and let us have Gloom well pleased.
Go now!
Well, since it is for Gloom...
I have the fireleaf, Father, but I am worried that the elder shall hold me to account for it.
I have the fireleaf, Father, but I am worried that the elder shall hold me to account for it.

Be at peace, child. All is under control. We shall make our offering to Gloom, and all shall pass.
In the meantime, here is the reward you have earned.
This is all mine? Why, thank you!
Asoveh, Wise One! Tell me of Abella

Of that, I am always glad to tell! Abella is an island of eternal blessing and blessedness. Every mortal who comes to Abella finds what he or she dreams of finding, for so it is written in our ancient scriptures.
There, the warrior shall find eternal battle and victory. The farmer, perpetual peace and prosperity. The craftsman, worthy work to the glory of himself and the gods. The king there shall find faithful subjects, and the subjects shall find a good, just ruler. Aye, and the slave shall find a good master, and the master a submissive slave. There the artist shall have no lack of paints, the butcher of meats, and the harlot of clients.
All is fair and just in Abella!
*Ulf pays you no mind*
Asoveh Svefnii!
I SAID, ASOVEH SVEFNII, BLACKSMITH!
I hear you. No need to yell. What do you want?
Teach me how to smelt.
Tell me, why do all insist I speak with the elder?
They are afraid.
Of me?

No, of the gods.
Our elder is a man of special quality. His gift is to see what is hidden. He shall see you, and if he recognizes any seal of foreign gods, he shall pronounce his word, and you shall hang to wither under the gaze of Amate.
A rope around your neck.
But you are not afraid?
I am a blacksmith. We have our own... accounts with the gods.
So you are favored? Do you speak with them?
No one speaks with the gods. They issue commands, and you must decide for yourself how to respond.
How does one respond if they simply issue commands, without any regard for our will?

Respond wisely.
It is not always best to bow before them, before our gods especially. Aorik was right, he was right, yet I did not believe...
Our elder listened to their commands, and covered the island with idols. And then with gallows, to hang men and women like you who come to this place.
Huh.

Aye. Wanted to serve all the gods. But the gods are jealous, and none can serve all of them. And they are harsh, as well, for all of them require many sacrifices. They thirst for blood. And for our Sparks...
Our lives?
Hello? Blacksmith?

<font:Open Sans Italic:20>Velent is darkness, blood wreathed in night, Amate is fire and light.
Johde is cold, howling cry of the wolves, Jomfru is sickness and blight.

<font:Open Sans Italic:20>Gloom grins eternal, playing his jokes, it looks joyful until you see it up close.
Sófaþek-king gives advice till you croak, full wisdom, e'en in lethal dose.

<font:Open Sans Italic:20>Sleep does the Flame, in gloomy abyss, Sleeps too his blade in the dark.
Sharp is the blood-scythe for harvest, for death,
and ripe is the bounty, the Sparks.

<font:Open Sans Italic:20>Tears of Kallente rain in the sky, like arrows of water they fly.
Children asleep in the ashes nearby,
their mother sings mad lullabies.
So by her mercies the ferryman's purse Hath great weight and greater still worth.
Blacksmith? What is going on?

What? I am busy. I must forge this sword... Sword... Ul... Ule... Ulf...
Begone! Now!
I take my leave.
I want to learn how to forge. Tell me about working with metal.

You? About metalworking? Well, hearken, then.
For metalworking, you shall require: First, a pickax and an ore mine. Second, diligence and the aid of the Sleeper, first Smith of our world.
Third, a bloomery, to melt the ore. Therein you need a crucible and coal or logs to fuel its fire.
Finally, you require a hammer.
Is that sufficient?

You? About metalworking? Well, hearken, then.
For metalworking, you shall require: First, a pickax and an ore mine. Second, diligence and the aid of the Sleeper, first Smith of our world.
Third, a bloomery, to melt the ore. Therein you need a crucible and coal or logs to fuel its fire.
Finally, you require a hammer.
Is that sufficient?
I get it now... I think.
I get it now... I think.

ere, listen.
Take some ore and place it into a furnace or a kiln. Heat it up. You'll need some fuel for that first. You could use some billets for it, but you'll run dry quick. Better get some coal. You can get charcoal from burning the billets in a kiln.
So. Raise the temperature as high as a thousand degrees continuously. Keep an eye on your charcoal. When the ore is heated up, you can melt the bars. For that, you need a crucible.
Now hand me the ore, I could use it.
Okay, I get it. Gotta go.
Okay, I get it. Gotta go.
Got it! I will try.
Got it! I will try.

Very well. From the beginning.
To forge something, you require ingots. I shall not provide them for you – many like you have come before, and you all just waste good metal. But there is another way.
We mine ore from the nearby mine, which perhaps you have seen. Take your pickax there and mine however much ore you need, but take care not to break the pickax in the process.

Very well. From the beginning.
To forge something, you require ingots. I shall not provide them for you – many like you have come before, and you all just waste good metal. But there is another way.
We mine ore from the nearby mine, which perhaps you have seen. Take your pickax there and mine however much ore you need, but take care not to break the pickax in the process.

Well, you seem pretty interested...
How does one forge? You don't, with that much experience. Hm-m, I guess nails should do.. it doesn't take a lot to make a nail.
Well, if you can figure it out, here's a free anvil and hammer. Care for it, and try not to break it. Take some lumps of iron in the crate, they'll come in handy.

Well, you seem pretty interested...
How does one forge? You don't, with that much experience. Hm-m, I guess nails should do.. it doesn't take a lot to make a nail.
Well, if you can figure it out, here's a free anvil and hammer. Care for it, and try not to break it. Take some lumps of iron in the crate, they'll come in handy.
Nah, it's nothing.
I see you already have a hammer. If you break it, forge another.
Here is a hammer for your use. Take care with it, and if it breaks, forge a new one. That will serve as good practice for you.
Here is a hammer for your use. Take care with it, and if it breaks, forge a new one. That will serve as good practice for you.
Thank you!
What is it?
Might I treat you with some fireleaf during our conversation?
You rich in fireleaf?
You rich in fireleaf?
Not especially. I simply have a question.
Then let us hear it.
I am in need of an ax for a certain job.
Take one from the chest, then. But be sure to return it thither.
You have my thanks. And one more question.
Duty calls. Farewell.
Might you lend me a saw? I am providing assistance to the carpenter.
There is a saw in the chest. Break it, though, and I shall smash you into the earth.
There is a saw in the chest. Take care not to break it.
I brought the ore. Ugh, it's so heavy.

What'd you expect?
Now ore should be melted down. I guess I could tell you what's what... but you won't be able to melt it 'ere. You need skill and experience for that.
I seek a metal shovel.
Retrieve it from the chest.
I wish to ask about the island.
Ask, then.
What is that tower of ships you have?
Ships stacked in a tower, you say? I see nothing but a cold, bright light. So that's how it is, then, huh...
Why are so many hanging here?
Our elder, following the voices in his head, incites the people to make sacrifices to the gods. In an attempt to please them. The fool.
I see you are building a ship...
We are. Abella awaits us.
Tell me about Abella

Abella is an island.
There is located Turneskangen, the Tower of the Branch, raised by the Lord to protect the Branch of the World Tree there. The Branches grow through all inhabited and uninhabited worlds, through the worlds of men and gods both, and perhaps even further.
As my grandfather would tell me, this Branch purifies our world, making rulers just and wise and commoners as happy as children.
And so we all yearn to go to Abella.
Gods be good, that has the sound of magic to it. Does it grant wishes?
Who?
The Branch?
Pfft. Not even our cook listens to wishes. Much less the Branch. Perhaps you should go check. Then you can tell me!
Pfft. Not even our cook listens to wishes. Much less the Branch. Perhaps you should go check. Then you can tell me!
I see. I take my leave, then.
Asoveh dendodeh Svefnii! Talked you with our elder?
Asoveh Svefnii! Not yet.

Until you do, I shall not speak to you.
Make your way to the elder, who is designated our leader. He shall see you and decide what sort of man you be. Whether a decent man or marked by Gloom. If he says you be like us, return and we will hold conversation.
Seek the elder in the communal building near the bell. The building is long and easily found.

Until you do, I shall not speak to you.
Make your way to the elder, who is designated our leader. He shall see you and decide what sort of woman you be. Whether a decent woman or marked by Gloom. If he says you be like us, return and we will hold conversation.
Seek the elder in the communal building near the bell. The building is long and easily found.
Then I will go see the elder.
Then I will go see the elder.
I have already spoken with the elder.
I have already spoken with the elder.
Then what do you want?
What do you want?
What do you want?
I've been assigned by the Elder to help the village. Should I plow the fields or something?

A good, eh-h... aspiration!
It's too late for plowing, though, but it's a great time for harvest. See what's there on our fields, gather what's growing from the land, and bring it back to our Hoytu-right-hanir. She'll have it all cooked right for the dinner.
And watch it! Don't stamp our fields too much.
Tell me about farming.

Agreed.
Farming be our whole basis for life here. 'Tis how we live! Everyone be always wanting to eat. What do you want to eat?
I eat whatever I can get my mouth on.

Then you be like my wife, peace on her ashes.
Fruits and vegetables, and all else edible that be growing from the earth, for cooking, for food, to eat. All be in need of eating. When you be full, you learn to craft and forge faster, but a hungry man, now he be a slow man, he be thinking of nothing but food. And be having nowhere to get it, heehee.
Flax, now that be something I respect, too. You cannot eat it beyond its seeds, but you can be wearing a shirt or pants spun from it. But to make them, you be needing skill.
I have more questions.
*Karegast scratches his beard*
I have questions about farming.
I be pleased to answer, then.
How can I grow a good harvest?

Growing a good harvest be a thing of great wisdom, passed from our ancestors to us. It be to feed the whole village. Hunters and fishers, that be a thing of great fortune or no, blessing of the gods or no. But to guarantee food for all people, that be found nowhere but in farming.
Yet it be not easy. First, you select a field, and plough the soil, and see that the seeds be not rotten, and be guessing well the weather. And when the land be good, the harvest be good.
For a surety, be not forgetful to appease the gods, for luck. You be needing much time for all of this, for farming cannot be hurried.
I have another question.
How can I "guess well" the weather?

No way to do that. But for your crop to be prosperous, the weather need be rotating. Shining of the sun, then raining of the sky, then the shining of Amate once again. Then, be it by the rule, your crop will grow.
How do I plough the land?

Well, I be with a question, now. Where did you come from, and how did they not take you? How to plough, good be the gods...
We plough with a plough, of a certainty! The plough be a fickle device, perilous for people like you. You be in need of skill, as always!
To make a plough, you be needing wheels, iron for the ploughshare, five pieces of linen, and wood.
Then be at watch you only plough fertile land. Keep an eye on the land, to be wary of clay, sand, rocks. Remember, fertile soil.

Well, I be with a question, now. Where did you come from, and how did they not take you? How to plough, good be the gods...
We plough with a plough, of a certainty! The plough be a fickle device, perilous for people like you. You be in need of skill, as always!
To make a plough, you be needing wheels, iron for the ploughshare, five pieces of linen, and wood.
Then be at watch you only plough fertile land. Keep an eye on the land, to be wary of clay, sand, rocks. Remember, fertile soil.
Could you lend me a plough for a while?

I be! Lend? You? And what if by your hand the ploughshare be bent? Reputation of a newcomer, all clumsy and amateur, prone to be breaking things.
Calm yourself, this be a better idea: a chest be behind the shed. In it be wheels and other important parts. So you make a plough for yourself.
I be your source of advice, if you find ought in which you need advising. Happy to be of help.

I be! Lend? You? And what if by your hand the ploughshare be bent? Reputation of a newcomer, all clumsy and amateur, prone to be breaking things.
Calm yourself, this be a better idea: a chest be behind the shed. In it be wheels and other important parts. So you make a plough for yourself.
I be your source of advice, if you find ought in which you need advising. Happy to be of help.
Could you share some fireleaf for our time together?

Would that I could, I be holding no greed and no stinginess towards a good person like yourself.
But if you be offering, then of course, I say yes. Laws of Kalle be against me insulting you by turning you away.
Wait, what?

You be deaf, I see. Happens.
I had a grandmother who was deaf, could not hear a thing, mayhap that be why she died being one hundred. Meaning she be too deaf to hear the calls of Johde and Jomfru. So the gods could not call her to take her. As so she would be living still, likely, to this day, except the gods be fed up with her and dropped a log on her.
Our life here be hard, I say. Hard as hell. On the island no dwelling to be built, no escape to be made. Only joys be eating and drinking khtynka.
And smoking of course. Oh right, you be deaf.
I SAID, BE YOU IN POSSESSION OF ANY FIRELEAF?

You be deaf, I see. Happens.
I had a grandmother who was deaf, could not hear a thing, mayhap that be why she died being one hundred. Meaning she be too deaf to hear the calls of Johde and Jomfru. So the gods could not call her to take her. As so she would be living still, likely, to this day, except the gods be fed up with her and dropped a log on her.
Our life here be hard, I say. Hard as hell. On the island no dwelling to be built, no escape to be made. Only joys be eating and drinking khtynka.
And smoking of course. Oh right, you be deaf.
I SAID, BE YOU IN POSSESSION OF ANY FIRELEAF?
Uh, I'm... here. Some fireleaf for you.

Now that be a different matter! With pleasure, we smoke to the glory of the gods, and most of all Kalle, Homekeeper she be.
And we be right to converse on our lives. If you be here with any questions, ask.
I be willing to answer!
I remember nothing from the time I crawled up onto this island's shore.
I remember nothing from the time I crawled up onto this island's shore.

So it goes, so it be with us all here. As I be of understanding, Gloom jokes with the heads of all who come to the island.
But we be accustomed to it, now, sometimes even shaking out pieces of memory from our minds, recalling what be forgotten.
Tell me more about the gods.

What be there to say of them? Our task it be to please them. I be in the know of all a farmer needs to know of it.
When you be in need of pleasing Gloom, wait for the moon to rise, drink some khtynka, then some sour milk, then go to your neighbor's field and relieve yourself there.
Then Gloom will be pleased and you will be unharmed by him for a time. Until the moon sets once more, that is. That is, when Velent cloaks not her beauty.
Gloom be a lover of jokes. And plays many jokes himself. Though his jokes be rarely loved by those they be upon.
So we farmers joke instead on one another, pleasing Gloom while Velent flies disrobed across the sky.
All I know about the gods be all I need to know. If you be wanting to hear legends on them, go speak with our Accur.
As the man says about me when he be drunk, I be a "pract *hic* al man." Not a man for legends.
Can you tell me of another?

Kalle of the Generous Womb be the one we farmers venerate. She blesses and multiplies our harvest.
When you be of the desire that your harvest abound, and no hail strike your crops, you turn your eye to your field...

Kalle of the Generous Womb be the one we farmers venerate. She blesses and multiplies our harvest.
When you be of the desire that your harvest abound, and no hail strike your crops, you turn your man's eye to your field...
Also at nighttime?

I see you be of a reasonable mind. Well done!
Yes, at night. Under the cover of Velent's cloak when the field is best sown.

I see you be of a reasonable mind. Well done!
Yes, at night. Under the cover of Velent's cloak when the field is best sown.
Do you need some khtynka for this?

Khtynka? Well, if there be some.
Drink some and go on the field. Kallente be a woman adoring the pleasures of love, and in the springtime she enters the earth, so...
Be sure you seize luck by the tail! Follow to the field, for Kalle will be waiting there for you.
And how well you please her, that rich will your harvest be. My field is always in the ear.
Not so my neighbors'.

Khtynka? Well, if there be some.
Drink some and go on the field. Kallente be a woman adoring the pleasures of love, and in the springtime she enters the earth, so...
Be sure your man seize luck by the tail! Tell him to watch your field, for Kalle will be waiting there for him.
And if he be pleasing to Kalle, so will the harvest be pleasing to you. And so my field be always in the ear.
Not so my neighbors'.
Farming is far from simple, I see.
I fear I have none.
Then be not a bother to busy people. I wish your departure well.
What is that tower of ships you have here?

Heehee, I can see Khoytu's khtynka be getting to you. It be pleasing to me, too, but drinking enough to see a tower of ships? That experience be not mine, as of yet. Or did you mayhap eat something... special? Be not secretive. Share! Perhaps I also be of the desire to see this tower of ships.

Heehee, I can see Khoytu's khtynka be getting to you. It be pleasing to me, too, but drinking enough to see a tower of ships? That experience be not mine, as of yet. Or did you mayhap eat something... special? Be not secretive. Share! Perhaps I also be of the desire to see this tower of ships.
And why are so many people hanging here?

They be monsters of men, being in refusal to recognize our gods, especially my dear Kallente, whom they were not of a desire to please, on my very field. So we hung them, to please the gods.
Another benefit of this be that the crows turn more eye to them than to my crops!
I see you are building a ship...
It be a marvelous ship, to carry us through the frigid sea, to the island which be of blessing and blessedness, Abella!
Tell me about Abella

Abella be a wondrous island of eternal blessing and blessedness. My grandfather said, and his grandfather before him, and his grandfather and great-grandfather before him, that wheat grows on the island all year around. Untended!
With ears the size of a woman's breast! So it be unnecessary to reap and sow but just to reach out your hand, pluck, and fill your belly for the day...
And the fireleaf there be strong and abundant! And so rich the gods themselves descend to partake. And Kalle walks the fields all year, always ready for, I mean...
Merciful is the Lord.
Who is that?
The one who created heaven and earth. And you and me.
Ah, is that your god?
He is not mine, but I am his. As are you, though you reside in darkness.
Uh, right, well I offer sacrifices to Svefnii the Fiery One, into the earth. And to Gloom. And to Kallente. And to whomever else.

Their name is legion.
If I had use of my arm, I would teach you how one should make sacrifices in nomine Dei! But the Lord is at work enlightening me with humility, and now my word is my weapon.
Ask your question.
Your look is different from that of the locals. Where do you hail from?
From far away. From a place called the Eternal City.
You were a warrior?
I was. And so I still am.
So you were a warrior, but your speech sounds like that of the Accur. Who are you?
Just a humble servant of God, who with the blessing of Father Clement the Peacemaker has been entrusted to bear the light of the true faith into the darkness of ignorance. Be it by word or sword.
So he is your father, this one who created worlds. Meaning you are his Son, Lightbearer. Got it.
So he is your father, this one who created worlds. Meaning you are his Son, Lightbearer. Got it.
Lord grant me longsuffering...
What is this place?
A circus. By the locals, called an Arena. A place for games and bloody spectacles.
I have noticed that this island's people have no place for violence, but sometimes I feel I could do for a good fight.
I have noticed that this island's people have no place for violence, but sometimes I feel I could do for a good fight.
Here, you may fight. Come spill blood in the Arena!
The people hung around the island are dressed as you are...
You are quite observant.
You are quite observant.
So that leads to the question, if you were their comrade, why are they hanging but you are not?

Even in the souls of the heathen, the Lord sometimes instills mercy. A battle raged between my brethren and the inhabitants of this island. I was wounded, nay, hacked apart, covered in sword slashes, and was offered to one of your idols.
But the mercy of God was shown to me, by the hand of the blacksmith, and delivered me from the Accur's rusty knife. And made the elder remember compassion.
Then a good woman whose name I cannot hope to pronounce nursed me to health, and my place came to be this Arena.
As you are a warrior, can you teach me a warrior's skill?
I shall not teach you.
Then at least give me some advice. In battle, what is the most important of all?
You again...
Asoveh! Will you advise me now? What is the most important thing of all in combat?

Many things are important.
Watch your breathing so that you have the strength to strike or dodge when the critical moment comes. This is called stamina. Limit your movement – do not run around, jump, or wave your weapon for no purpose. Be of a cold and calculating mind, saving your energy for when the time is right. And when that time comes, do not miss it.

Keep unceasing watch on the distance between you and your adversary, so that when you swing your weapon, you hit with its edge or point, or whichever part is intended to wound. Any farther, and you will not reach – any closer, and you will strike with the shaft of your spear or hilt of your sword, and that will be the end of you.
Well...

One more thing: remember that the force of impact depends on both your stance and speed. Ground yourself with both your feet, stand in place, and your blow will be strong. A blow while moving is weaker, but also faster. Use this difference wisely, to your advantage.
