A Gottlung plate helm with a solid visor. The blacksmith's brand is illegible.
A shiny, solid breastplate with a chain gorget and massive pauldrons.
A pair of heavy plate bracers. Black straps of tawed leather are hidden beneath a layer of plates.
Plate gauntlets assembled from tiny plates of blackened metal. A Gottlung pattern has been carved into the cuffs, which are polished to a shine.
Blackened plate greaves on a solid chain-mail base.
A pair of leather boots covered with blackened steel plates that protect the foot on all sides. Very durable and, believe it or not, comfortable footwear.
A flat-topped Gottlung helm with quilted lining.
A tempered breastplate that retains traces of numerous blows. The metal is solid, light, and has been very lightly blackened — a telltale sign of Gottlung armor.
Well-worn bracers made of blackened metal.
Gottlung-made plate gauntlets. The overlapping thick plates fastened on a coarse leather base protect the arm against blows.
Solid quilted leggings with heavy, battle-scarred greaves.
Infantry boots with a layer of plate mail — inexpensive, but well made. The ankles and heels are covered with a chain netting.
A flat Gottlung helm. It's a little worn and has a barely-noticeable reddish tint to its numerous nicks.
A thin chainmail shirt with pauldrons, a forged gorget, and iron plates protecting the stomach and sides. Roughly, but competently made.
Well-worn leather bracers with iron patches fastened onto them.
Coarse gauntlets sewn together from patches of leftover bull hide. On the back of the hand is an iron plate held on with rivets.
Quilted leggings with round iron greaves bound by straps.
These shoes are soft, durable, and have steel soles.
A shiny plate helm with a thin layer of gilt and a barely noticeable engraving on the visor.
A burnished breastplate with the visage of Amate finely engraved upon it. Golden rays emanate from her countenance.
Blackened bracers covered with a tooled Gottlung pattern and words of prayer engraved upon it.
Luxurious gauntlets lined with red silk. They are covered with steel plates with a thin layer of gilt.
Knight's greaves with gilded knee protectors. They are assembled from numerous pieces riveted together. Truly fine work.
Plate boots fitted precisely to the foot. Burnished, gilded plates with an engraving are fastened onto a calfskin base.

This helm is thin, light, and completely lacking in durability. It is made from some kind of soft metal and has a leather lining. Leather flaps with irregular iron scales sewn onto them rest against the warrior's neck and shoulders.
A peasant's overcoat sewn with sinew and decorated with broad, sandy-colored trim. A single layer of scales has been sewn onto it.
Ox leather bracers with iron scales sewn unevenly onto them.
Khoors leather gauntlets with no lining, slightly reinforced with thick pads on the back of the hands.
Broad leggings made from thick felt and dyed brown, the color of the steppe. Scale greaves protect the legs just below the knees.
Boots sewn with sinew that have sturdy leather soles. Rope and scraps of old cloth have been wrapped around them for increased toughness.
A helm made from plates of soft iron of the lowest quality. The top of the helm is adorned with a horse's tail.
A thick tunic with a layer of leather over it. Even rows of long iron scales are sewn across it.
Scale bracers made of leather and sturdy sackcloth sewn with ox sinew.

These gauntlets are made from several layers of rough treated leather and stitched with "coarse" thread along the edge. It's quite heavy – there are probably steel scales sewn in underneath the lining.
Felt leggings that end in leather bootlegs thickly covered with metal scales.
Durable and yet very soft boots with scuffed tips. Thick leather straps with iron scales are wrapped around them.
A pointed helm made of surprisingly decent iron. It is decorated with bronze plates and a tail fastened to the top.

This tunic edged with wolf fur is surprisingly sturdy and heavy. The waves of thick steel scales aren't sewn on, but fastened to one another in an overlapping pattern – no spear or sword can get past them. The edges and sides are decorated with engraved leather pads.
Comfortable bracers made from two layers of tanned leather and reinforced with sturdily fastened iron feathers.
Riveted leather gauntlets, a surprisingly fine job for steppe-dwellers. The fingers are protected with iron plates.
Comfortable, wide leggings made of skillfully treated leather with numerous faceted scales made from uncommonly good steel sewn onto them.
Snub-nosed leather boots richly adorned with copper plates. Warm and soft, but surprisingly sturdy, with steel feathers sturdily sewn into the calf and instep.

A pointed helmet decorated with various designs and a fire-red tail. It is covered with a thin layer of glossy lacquer, probably to protect the gilded depiction of galloping steeds, sabers, and great burial mounds drawn in a frame made of tongues of flame.

A very solid, sturdy, and painstakingly made peasant blouse covered with thick steel scales fastened in several rows. The leather is dyed bright red and adorned with patterns sewn with gold and red thread.
Solid leather bracers adorned with copper rivets with pictures of horses' heads on them.
Leather gauntlets dotted with rivets. Quite sturdy and solid in order to protect the arm against spears and swords. They are decorated with a complex tooled pattern.
A black and red skirt-like article of clothing made of smooth silk covers sturdy leggings made of felt and leather topped with tiny steel scales.
These boots are richly adorned with tiny gilded scales and sewn with dark red thread. They are lined with calfskin and some kind of short, thick fur.
A helm made of a thin chain netting. Something like sackcloth has been sewn onto it.
Short chain mail with no sleeves, woven in two layers. It is decorated with a simple, shapeless wolf hide collar.
These bracers are made of sturdy canvas that have been soaked in something.
Simple northern leggings – not too pretty, but sturdy, warm, and comfortable. The chain patches are sewn on with coarse thread protect the warrior's legs just below the knees.

The northerners have never been particularly skilled shoemakers, and these boots are proof of that. The soles and the boots themselves are made of rough cow leather with fur on the inside. Soft straps have been sewn onto the shapeless bootlegs, allowing the boots to fit the foot snugly.
Roughly made fingerless gauntlets made of thick, coarse leather.
A sturdy, well-made Slavard helm. Simple, with no attempt at elegance, and with a think aventail lined with sackcloth to protect the ears and neck.
The inside of this forged helm shines through the thin eye-holes of the wolf's head. A thin chain aventail is sewn to the fur to form a kind of lining.
Chain mail made from large rings. Not especially thick, but surprisingly light and durable. A wolf-fur collar rests on the back, providing the wearer with additional protection and warmth.
A chain-mail bracer with steel ribs and coarse leather lining.
Insulated gauntlets made from tanned leather with straps hidden on the wrists.
Sailor's boots made of rough leather. Simple, durable, and double-stitched. A chain netting is concealed behind the opening to protect the calves.
Canvas pants. They are sturdy, insulated, and have pockets for a pipe, flint and tinder, and other soldier's things.
A sturdy steel skullcap decorated with ornamental script. The warrior's face is hidden behind steel defenses, and the nape of the neck is protected by an aventail.
Inside the bear's head is a steel helm with a mask and a chain aventail covering the warrior's neck.
This chain mail is made from tiny steel rings. The rings are woven together so thickly that they resemble fish scales. The long skirts and sleeves are adorned with runes and carved bone talismans.
Bracers made of cow leather with a solid netting of forged steel rings.
Woven chain gauntlets with a soft wolf-fur lining.
Pants made of dyed canvas. They look deceptively light, but on the inside they are lined with wolf fur and thin strips of chain mail to protect the calves and thighs against blows.
Chain mail boots insulated with bear fur. Sturdy and reliable, they have numerous laces and straps that allow them to be fitted precisely to the foot.
A gilded helm with a riveted nasel and a bear's head. A sign of a jarl or a field commander from his retinue.

Thick chain mail that reaches down to the knees assembled from rune-marked links. On the chest are leather pads with engraved ornaments. This armor is an item of rare durability and beauty. A fine piece of work indeed.
The lining of these bracers is bright crimson and made from uncommon, shimmering fabric probably acquired on a campaign. The bracer itself is made of tiny rings of tempered steel.
Well-made chain-mail gauntlets. They are lined with thick, fluffy fur and laced with red ribbon.

Leggings like a layer cake. They feature canvas with runes sewn into them, leather for durability, and fur for warmth. They are reinforced with a chain netting. Few spears can pierce leggings such as these.

Sewn to fit the foot precisely, these chain-mail boots will serve their owner faithfully through many battles and campaigns. Bear fur coated with lard protects against the fiercest frost, and the talismans and runes sewn into the crimson lining protect against other manners of peril.
A sewn cap. It is soft and stuffed with linen rags.
Simple, light leather armor with canvas sleeves and a woolen hood in case of rain or snow.
Shapeless bracers sewn together from scraps of old leather. They are lined with small pieces of cloth scraps.
These shapeless gauntlets are made of pigskin. They might not look like much, but they do protect the arms.
Simple canvas pants reinforced with strips of leather. They are light and durable to a certain point.
Shoes with wooden soles held on with fish glue. They are made of pigskin coated with lard.
A leather helm with a band on the inside. Iron scale is sewn inside the nasel.
A cuirass made of boiled leather with riveted, lined steel plates.
Thick bracers made of three layers of boiled leather riveted along the edges. They are fastened to the arm with two broad straps.
Gauntlets made of solid leather with long, broad cuffs designed to resemble Gottlung plate gauntlets. The fingers are made of dark leather and are more finely crafted.
These leggings are made of coarse leather and reinforced with riveted patches in the most vulnerable places.
Leather boots with thick, spongy soles. Instead of laces, the calves are wrapped in several soft straps.
This heavy helm only looks like pure leather – both the helm and its flaps are actually made of steel plates riveted together and covered with leather and tooled designs.
This leather armor is somewhat reminiscent of plate mail – it has plates covering the chest and shoulders and a gorget to protect the neck, and it weighs a little less than plate mail.
Each of these bracers are assembled from a dozen steel plates sewn into leather sleeves covering the forearms. They are tightened using laces.
Heavy, well-made gauntlets made of boiled leather. They are reinforced with steel scales sewn into the top. The fingers are made of thin, light leather.
Broad leggings with barely noticeable strips of riveted leather. They are well made and soft, yet durable.
Heavy boots made of matte leather. They are double-stitched and painstakingly made. Both the boots themselves and the straps on them are adorned with buckles and rivets in various shapes.
A heavy helm made of steel with richly decorated, tooled leather sewn around it. The edging and patterns are gilded.
A leather cuirass with steel plates sewn into it and a blood-red collar made of thin leather. Buckles and tiny fasteners, dozens of rivets – it's all gilded and shines with a noble luster.
Thick plates of tempered steel are sewn beneath dyed red leather covered with tooled patterns.

These solid, expensive-looking gauntlets are covered with thin plates of gilded steel. The fingers are made of strips of black boiled leather, and the insides of the gauntlets are made of soft, red satin.
Thick laced leggings made of specially treated leather. They are covered with riveted leather patches to protect the knees and calves.
Boots made of expensive, soft leather. They are decorated with gilded iron buckles and dark red leather straps.
A coarse, quilted, laced helm. It is stuffed with something that's not quite oakum and not quite fur and is permeated with salt to the point of crackling.
A puffy quilted jacket stitched with horsehair. It is stuffed with scrap fabric and oakum and gives off a light, musty aroma.
These aren't bracers at all – they're linen rags fastened on with thin straps with no buckles.
Quilted fingerless gloves. They make a crunching sound when you make a fist in them – there must be straw inside. They might look rustic, but they provide some protection against arrows.
Linen pants with bindings sewn along rough, wobbly seams in a criss-cross pattern. There are patches made of folded-over pieces of sackcloth on the knees.
Short boots made of solid fabric soaked in lard.
A laced quilted helm with ear flaps. It is made thicker with waste cloth around the top of the head, nape of the neck, and temples and stuffed with matted wool.
A puffy quilted helm stuffed with cloth scraps and matted wool hidden under a raggedy boar's head with it's eyes sewn shut.
A quilted jacket made of several layers of solid linen with sleeves and an insulated back and lower back. Soaked in salt and stuffed with oakum and waste cloth.
Pieces of white linen cloth folded into several layers and carefully sewn into rather sturdy bracers.
Quilted gauntlets insulated with boar fur. Their solid leather lining provides good protection for the hands and preserves warmth.
Insulated cloth pants with rhombuses sewn onto the knees and calves.
Tall boots. They're warm, but hastily made. It's almost as if they're inside out, with seams on the outside and fur on the inside.
A helm made of strips of coarse, uneven iron riveted onto a thick quilted lining stuffed with oakum and fur. The warrior's face is protected by an iron half-mask.

The head of this old, battle-scarred boar makes an excellent helm – it has solid lining with strips of leather sewn into it and a steel skull cap with a half-mask that covers the warrior's eyes and nose.
A quilted tunic. It is sturdy and has a fur lining soaked in salt casks. It is covered with ribbons of thick, hard leather in a criss-cross pattern.
Broad bracers made of tanned leather with a cloth lining.
Warm gloves made of leather and lined with cloth scraps and horsehair.
Puffy cloth pants sewn from three layers of fabric with oakum and straw stuffed between them. They're warm, and they can take a hit well.
These boots look shapeless, but on the inside they have high wooden soles, hard leather legs that cling to the calves, and fur lining.
This helm's steel ribs are hidden under a boar's head stuffed full of scraps of cloth and leather.
Heavy padded armor made of three layers of dyed linen. Under a lining of black boar fur hides coarse, solid fabric with strips of leather sewn into it.
Bracers the color of frozen blood. They are made of leather, stuffed with matted wool, and carefully riveted in a circle.

Judging from their softness and flexibility, these gauntlets are made of calfskin that has been treated and prepared in a special way. On the inside they are sewn like padded armor and lined with numerous rivets that are hard to spot in the thick fur lining.
Thick linen leggings made from four layers of crimson fabric with layers of horsehair and matted wool in-between.
These boots are made of solid, rough leather with red fabric sewn around them. They are insulated with thick fur.
A two-handed sword with a long hilt wrapped in tawed straps. It has a short ricasso and a sharp, heavy blade with deeply engraved runes.

A simple zweihander with short, three-edged fangs. It is surprisingly evenly sharpened. It is simply constructed, but made with noticeable skill and has a certain ineffable elegance to its appearance. The base of the blade has the words "ad patres" carved into it — a curt message to anyone who might stand in the way of this weapon's owner.

Mercenaries like these swords for their simple shape and perfect balance — the lead-filled hilt excellently balances the heavy blade with its long ricasso. "Ad hominem," intone the slender letters carved into the sword — an irony that perhaps only the sword's owner can appreciate.

The Eye of the Sleeper can be glimpsed in the gilded guard of this two-handed sword. The phrase "ultima ratio" is carved into the blade in ornamental script that is smooth and soft-edged, as though pressed into the surface of the sword.

This sword is a copy of the legendary lost sword known as "Terskel." Strips of studded leather form an intricate pattern on the hilt, and a gilded hand gripping the horn Rivelim form the fangs of this sword. The ornate guard is covered in a thin layer of gilt.

A massive, roughly forged axe on a long, light pole. It has a small butt and a curved blade with northern runes writ upon it in the shape of a crescent moon. Its rustic appearance is deceptive — this is a reliable weapon that is easy to wield and quite powerful for its weight.

This axe with a handle wrapped in strips of leather and a curved blade is not without a certain coarse, idiosyncratic beauty. Its charm may lie in the simple angular pattern carved inside of the axe — a hallmark of the northern blacksmiths.
A Slavard axe with a beveled butt and a long, straight, thick blade. In the northern lands this axe is known as a "bruiser's axe," as though calling attention to the weapon's personality and status.

An unusually thin axe handle on a straight pole wrapped in iron and leather strips. The blade is bronze-plated and covered in shallow, yet clearly visible runes. Like a spell whispered over the weapon by an enchanter, they protect the warrior from doom and misfortune.

Compared to the Slavards' artlessly simple weapons this axe is especially good. The dragon head on the butt with its whimsically winding gilded pattern is not just a frame for the sharp blade made from tempered steel – it is an ancient warrior's talisman, a special, almost palpable force that protects the axe's owner.

The kind of weapon an armed troll or a cannibal might wield. It looks truly terrifying. There are several notches – perhaps the number of the weapon's victims, or perhaps simply a design to enhance its beauty – on the pole made from dried pine. The toothed blade, which known neither runes, nor family crest, nor even a blacksmith's brand, has been sharpened unevenly, and the metal seems to be stained with blood.

Whether re-forged from a sword or an axe, this glaive has an odd shape and is adorned in the northern tradition. Its long, contracted blade is tipped with the image of a god – apparently the trickster Gloom, beloved by raiders. The hilt has been fortified with a metal sleeve and strips of coarse leather.

The name of this glaive means "The Way of Pain" in the Slavard tongue. The blade's unusual shape has been augmented with dragon's teeth and a long, sharpened hook that is equally good for parrying enemy blows and disemboweling foes.

Blackened metal, flawlessly forged and with hooks in complex shapes. This Gottlung glaive once belonged to one of the warrior priests of the Vaktaarkangen brotherhood, who are famed for their inhuman cruelty and skill in battle.

The blade is adorned with an image of the sun-faced goddess holding a sacrificial sickle of the kind best used to pull horsemen from their steeds or sever tendons. The pole is wrapped in tooled leather.
This weapon resembles a tongue of flame frozen into a hunk of tempered steel. Bronze and gilt play upon the wide, sharp blade on a pole wrapped in morocco straps.

A long, triangular blade with a pristinely smooth, razor-sharp edge. Glaive is adorned with the Eye, crafted out of slivers of gilt steel. Yew wood and thin strips of leather lead to an austere yet elegant pommel finish
A rather fanciful hat made of blue silk with a rough canvas band fitted tightly around the head. Hats like these are typically worn by small-time merchants, town criers, and scribes.
A jaunty hat with a bent brim made of thick, aged leather.
Hats with bent brims like this one are frequently worn by traveling merchants. Its soft leather lining is solid enough to protect against wind and rain.
Simple, rough headwear – a white canvas hood sewn onto a wide-brimmed straw hat as a kind of lining.
A hat with ear flaps made of coarse linen and fringed with wool. It's not much to look at, but it's warm.
A skullcap with fur on the inside. A short tail hangs down from the back to carefully cover the nape of the wearer's neck.
A tall fur-lined hat with a leather hood rakishly cocked to one side.
A skullcap made of horse hide stitched roughly and irregularly. Its warm, sturdy felt lining is turned slightly inside-out to resemble a fur border.
A hat made of crimson goat leather with some kind of dark fur with red spots – probably dog – sewn around it.
A tall hat made of ox hide. It has been poorly dyed with brown and red stripes.
Unimpressive-looking pointed shoes with boiled leather soles. The thin rope laces literally fall apart in your hands, leaving red fibers on your fingers.
These boots are made of cow leather. They are sturdy, shapeless, and have enormous bootlegs that slap against the calves with each step.
Boots with bent tips that fit the foot snugly. Indispensable footwear among Khoors horsemen.
Boots like these are made of pieces of thick felt. They are surprisingly warm and almost waterproof and can last for years.
Shoes with no tips made of coarse linen and leather scraps.
Short shoes with thin straps. Simple, but with a pretense to elegance.
Rough peasant shoes with wooden heels that make a loud clacking sound when you walk.
Rustic gauntlets made of two layers of solid linen. They might protect you against work-related callouses, but they won't do much against the cold.

A bascinet made from excellent Gottlung steel. The visor with narrow eye-slits has been polished to a fine sheen. The helmet itself is framed in a barely-visible leaf ornament and decorated with stripes of black and white lacquer.

A luxurious forged cuirass with a gorget and shoulders made from small polished plates. The breastplate is adorned with black and white stripes, and words of prayer shine upon it with the dull glimmer of gilt.

A plate bracer adorned with black and white stripes. It covers the elbow and forearm well but is still light and mobile. It is decorated with monograms drawn in black lacquer and lined with soft leather on the inside.

These warm, comfortable gauntlets are made from soft leather treated in a special manner. The inside of the gauntlets is lined with overlapping plates of tempered steel that can even withstand a blow from a poleaxe.
Chainmail pants made of tiny rings of blackened steel and ending in steel greaves. The polished metal is decorated with an engraving, and the plates on the greaves are joined with gilded rivets.
Knight's boots made of steel plates. Despite their weight, they are rather comfortable and do not hamper the wearer's movements.
Beneath the lining of this luxurious conical helmet hides a sturdy aventail framed with blackened steel plates. The warrior's face is protected by a mask of pure silver.
This long-hemmed tunic is covered with hundreds of steel scales, and the pauldrons, sleeves, and hems are elegantly adorned with golden trim.
A wave of triangular scales streams down the shoulders of these bracers, ending in sleeves made of several thick plates linked by elegant gilded buckles.
These gauntlets are somehow ungainly, being made entirely from tiny plates of polished steel. On the inside is a silk lining tied to the edges of the gauntlets by thick golden trim.
Soft pants made of ox leather covered with square steel plates as smooth as mirrors.

These boots are comprised of forged steel shoe and soft leather tops covered with rows of overlapping steel plates. Straps that help to fit the boot snugly to the foot are hidden under some of the plates.
A menacing horned helmet. A gilded half-mask and a long, thick aventail reaching all the way down to the warrior's chest are attached to the forged headpiece.
This long chainmail tunic is striking thanks to its abundance of detail. It is thickly woven and has a forged breastplate to which a fur cloak with a chainmail backing is attached with straps.
Chainmail bracers with leather lining and large plates covering the most vulnerable areas.
Gauntlets made of the smallest rings. They are durable enough to protect the arm and thin enough not to interfere with the warrior's grip. The back of the hand is decorated with silver-plated plates.
Pants made of strips of ring mail. They stand apart from most similar armor thanks to the unparalleled quality of the weaving and their forged greaves with patterns tooled along the edges.
Boots made of strips of ring mail with steel tops. Made of calfskin, they are sturdy on the outside and soft and comfortable on the inside.
A pointed helmet reminiscent of a Khoors tent. The top part is forged, and the helmet itself is made of several layers of thick studded leather and outfitted with a steel nose-guard.
A tastefully made and decorated calfskin overcoat with a broad crimson belt and a felt doublet that can absorb hacking blows. It is reinforced with studded-leather and steel plates.
A pair of leather bracers made of pieces of boiled leather riveted together. They are stitched for greater sturdiness. The elbows are protected with steel plates.
Leather gauntlets with soft cuffs. They are lined with black silk sewn with silvery thread. They fit the hand... well, like a glove.

These leather greaves are made of layers of lacquered leather riveted together in an overlapping pattern. The abundance of rivets, tooled decorations, and patterned trim make them uniquely elegant and beautiful items.
Short dark-red morocco boots. They appear deceptively light, but penetrating them isn't easy – their tops are reinforced with two layers of studded leather that reliably protect the warrior's legs.

A skullcap made of tempered steel with a quilted aventail. Double-stitched sturdy silk thread combines two layers of soft leather lined with horsehair and a fine chainmail netting that cannot be seen from the side.

A light quilted jacket that fits the torso perfectly and is carefully conceived – behind the rabbit-fur lining is a layer of sticky boiled leather, and the most vulnerable areas are protected by thin steel plates.
Magnificently crafted quilted bracers adorned with stripes of blue-black leather.
Gauntlets made from several layers of coarse linen lined with pieces of tanned leather. Sturdy enough to stop a spear or soften a blow from a club.
Quilted greaves. Strips of yarn, horsehair, and some chainmail netting can be felt through the dark-blue fabric. The greaves nevertheless provide excellent protection.
Boots made from thin leather covered with rhombuses of quilted linen. They would be weightless if not for the steel plates sewn inside of them to protect the calf and instep.

This clothing might be simple, but it is also skillfully made. You won't find any tiny scraps or a sackcloth lining here. The sleeves and hems are adorned with subtle ribbons and embroidery. The seams may be coarse, but they are also sturdy, and the fabric is decent. A shirt like this will keep your back from getting too sweaty while plowing the fields.
Peasant attire – simple, but elegant. The sleeves and hems are sewn with ribbons and patterned trim. The clothing itself is dyed bright colors and almost seems to glow.
This novice's robe with a soft white tunic looks solemn and strict. The coal-black cloak worn over it is trimmed with symbols sewn with crimson and white silk.

A black shirt with a leather apron covering the smith's body and legs. One's gaze becomes lost in the crimson patterns and symbols, the secret nature of which is known only to Accurs and the smiths themselves. The interwoven symbols frame a ruby Eye of the Sleeper with a sheen of metal dust. The apron is belted with a thin woven belt on which tongs and small hammers are hung in strict order to make sure that every tool is available and in the right place.

A foppish getup worn by city-dwelling carpenters and joiners. Apparently this kind of clothing is, to a large extent, a sign of mastery and a symbol of belonging to the profession, but it is also especially good for work — convenient pockets sewn onto the apron and jacket, sturdy, dirt-resistant pants made of boiled leather, and loops on the straps for tools.

A decorated potion-brewer's cloak made of magenta linen. It is light and spacious, but fits very well, with sleeves with strings for greater comfort. This outfit has a special feature: a belt not unlike a sword belt on which hang countless chubby flasks of smoky glass.

A crimson shirt adorned with dull golden patterns. From the outfit's countless tassels hang bronze tools whose names are known only to the engineers themselves... if they are known to anyone at all. Measurements and angles, which are absolutely necessary for various drafting and engineering projects, are sewn into the leather jacket, which is belted with a broad belt.

A cook's outfit — a blue cotton vest, a shirt of light-colored linen, and, most importantly, a broad apron made of white fabric with pockets for salt and spices, as well as countless straps. A handy thing for attaching knives, spoon, ladles, and other crucial cooking utensils to.
The Sleeper's dream of you has ended. Whose life will be in his next dream?
Holza the spinner has finished your cloth. But wait... here is one more thread.
Have you lived with dignity? The Hammer will tell you.
Gloom's smile crossed the sky.
Gods' laughter shakes the darkness ...
Johde's sickle reddens.
Ulf's Crate
Ulf's Chest
Crate of the One-armed
The Elder's Chest
The Peasant's Chest
Dusty Crate
Crate of the Cook
Do not take what is not yours.
Take the shovel.
Take the nails.
Take the saw.
Take the axe.
Inspect the crate.
Steal the fireleaf.
Take the khtynka.
Take the wheels and rope.
Take the mushrooms.
The crate smells of damp earth.
*The old rusty tools lie in the chest.*
Close the chest.
But then why are you sitting here, not feasting like Gloom in the halls of Isenbrust? With the heavenly maidens and all that...
But then why are you sitting here, not feasting like Gloom in the halls of Isenbrust? With the heavenly maidens and all that...
Just to say hello. I'll go.

Certainly! Aid with mah hunting I require.
Ye recall that many come hither, a great multitude, all looking to stuff their faces. Our cook prepares scran for them. Do ye ken her, the beauty aye toiling by the cauldron?
Me being a hunter, I pursue fish and beast, but the need has outgrown mah capacity.
Assist me with the wild game. For this, ye will need a weapon, be it ax or sling.

What tower? Where? I not build any tower. I build a dive an' dip.
Where'd yer tower come from? Hit yer 'ead somewhere? Go get a khtynka from our cook to get rid o' those harmful thoughts. Good strong stuff straight fra' the steppes.

My child, the time has come for me to plant yet another grain of wisdom into your unreasoned mind.
Since ancient times there have existed invisible spiritual laws, laws not established by us. Every decent person must respect such laws or receive all sorts of terrible troubles upon their head.
Liars and perjurers, deceivers and murderers, robbers and other harmers of men and women violate these invisible laws.
So why do you, dear one, attempt to cheat this humble servant of the gods? For this your unforgivable act, you shall receive inescapable and terrible punishment.
Subscription
You can not drop this item.
The item will be destroyed.
This item can not be transferred.
You have successfully cancelled the resizing of the claim territory.
You can not enter the game worlds yet. Visit our website (lifeisfeudal.com) for a detailed schedule.
Grass will cover your sword.
Johde's sickle has crossed the thread of your life. Yet Holza-spinner catches it. What next?
However, the Sleeper rejects your Spark. You are not ready to become a part of the Sword of Revenge...
And fall through the darkness to the palm of Flamehaired Amate. She looks at you with contempt, laughs and then...
Rest in peace. And pray to The Maiden of a Red Sickle to give you another chance…
This is the end of pain and suffering. Peace and darkness at last. And eternal silence. However, you can...
The life is broken. But not the flame and anvil of the Sleeper awaits you, Johdenandhe has made her snowy bed ready for you... Hell no!
The darkness swallowed you. Only Gloom the Jester's flute cries. Its sound comes closer and closer but then...
Johde's red sickle has ended your path. But Gloom the Jester shows you the new one…
Velent calls your Spark to her halls. When you nod, unable to refuse, she laughs and...
A warrior in a horned helm throws the dice. They rattle swirl, jumps and when they finally settle your face is on top on one of them.
Sickle and Flute, Gloom and Johde. They argue over who will get that hot Spark. You. But you make one step back to the light and...
The cold shore comes out of an icy fog. The rigging creaks and the Gavran turns back, carrying you away...
But the Hammer's rumble is so distant that it is barely heard. No. You need to go back.
The woman's face, touched by time, peers at you from the emptiness. Her thin fingers spin, weaving the torn thread.
Red sickle halts near your chest, ready to be dug in. But no, Johde leaves. The Spark lights up once again under your ribs, warming the heart.
You are floating, carried away by water to cold and darkness. But, through the waves and foam, a light glimpses. You see a ship and human voices.
Iceeyed's cold fingers caress you distantly and carelessly. Twisting her lips, she pushes you away, and you...
“It is not your time yet” — says the one-handed old man...

Kallente is the goddess of beauty, motherhood, and fertility. She is patroness of the hearth and home, and thus of the lovers' embrace.
Go ahead and ask Karegast. He is an expert on serving Kallente, hah!
God wants coins!
User authorization in Xsolla services has failed. Some features can be unavaialbe. Try to restart the game.
On earth recently watered by the rain you spy the edge of a sunken, hastily dug hole. You dig up the soil to find a small pagan amulet.
Your shovel digs into the earth with a crunch and suddenly clangs against something. It is a small black amulet with a barely decipherable engraving. It seems the gods have sent you a gift...
Something bites you in the foot as you cross the shallow stream. In the white riverside sand you find a small, dark talisman made slippery by the overgrown seaweed.

You hear someone calling to you in a quiet, familiar voice. The voice calls so intently and insistently that you feel uneasy. Looking down at your feet you notice a wooden amulet lying among the rocks. You pick it up and realize that you can no longer hear the voice.

A pile of round, water-smoothed pebbles gleams white among the short grass, as if waiting just for you. As you approach the stones you realize that they are covering a simple hiding place. In a shallow hole covered with dried-up leaves you find a wooden talisman.

The soil here is rough, rocky, and stubborn. Your pickaxe sends clusters of sparks up into the air that fade quickly. During one brief flash you notice a small wooden talisman lying on the floor of the tunnel.

What luck! In the hollow of a fallen tree you discover a damp purse made of crimson brocade that falls apart in your hands. Your joys is fleeting, however – there is almost nothing inside... just a small pagan figurine carved from wood.
When you reach the very top of the spreading apple tree you discover an amulet tied to the trunk with a red ribbon.

Tasks
Dialog
Task description
Talk with the Ferryman in the tower under the pillar of light and head to Abella.
A single road runs along the shore to the village.
The elder has offered the community building as a place to stay. I can use a Prayer for Homecoming to return there.

You need a shovel to dig. To make one, break off a couple of tree branches and bind them together using plant fibers. You can find the fibers on the ground.
Or borrow a shovel from the Blacksmith.
The Gravedigger said to look for baromsag in clay. There should be clay deposits to the south of the village.
Tell the Gravedigger that you didn't find baromsag...
You should look for mushrooms on the forest floor at the base of trees.
The Gravedigger's waiting for his mushrooms.
The Hunter's told you that you need a branch and plant fibers to make a fishing pole. You can break off a tree branch and find plant fibers on the ground.
Catching fish isn't hard with a fishing pole. Just stand on the bank and keep casting it in until something bites.
Return to the Hunter with your catch.

You need weapons to hunt. You can make a slingshot out of a branch and plant fibers; everything you need for a slingshot that hurls stones can be collected from the ground.
An ax used for cutting down trees is also a decent weapon.

Choose an animal you're up to the task of subduing. You won't get far using your fists against a bear, for example: a sow or deer would be a better choice. You need a knife to carve up the animal; you can make one from a branch and flint stone.
Return to the Hunter with the dead animal's meat.
Break off a tree branch, collect fibers from the ground, find a flint stone and bind it to the branch, and your ax is ready! Or ask the blacksmith for one.
You'll need to use the branch and even more flint stons. You can ask the blacksmith for it.
You should cut down trees outside the village. You can saw the fallen logs into boards.
Return to the Carpenter with the boards.
With the necessary skills, you can make nails at the forge. Or ask the blacksmith; he might share some with you.

You need a saw to make a crate. Start building a crate on an empty bit of land: a placard will mark where you've begun construction. Place the boards and nails in the spot indicated by the placard and finish building the crate.
Make a crate and report back to the Carpenter.
There's a swamp near some fields to the south-east of the village. You can look for the Cook's children there.
Break off a tree branch, collect fibers from the ground, find a flint stone and bind it to the branch, and your hammer is ready!
Build a shack behind the village.
Tell Lodur that the shack's ready.
Finding alcohol in the village isn't difficult. If it's taking you a long time, visit the kitchen.
The Accur has requested some khtynka.
There should be some chicken coops near the bell tower.
Collect up the dung so that the chickens have a clean coop. The dung might come in handy as fertilizer.
Collect all the eggs the chickens laid.
The Accur has requested eggs.
A road leads to the Pagan Sanctuary via the field of idols. At the end of the road is a clearing that's suitable for installing new idols.
Praise your gods in the hopes of washing away your sins. Keep doing so until your entreaties have been heard. But not more than once a day.
Check the elder's chest in the Longhouse.
The Accur has requested some fireleaf.
Break off a tree branch, collect fibers from the ground, find a flint stone and bind it to the branch, and your saw is ready! Or ask the Blacksmith for one.
A road leads to the Pagan Sanctuary via the field of idols. At the end of the road is a clearing that's suitable for installing new idols.

Cut down a tree and saw the fallen trunk into a log. Start building an idol on an empty bit of land: a placard will mark where you've begun construction. Put the log on the spot indicated by the placard and finish building the idol.
Break off a tree branch and bind a flint stone to it using plant fibers. You can find the plant fibers and flint stone on the ground.
The road heading north leads to a mountain where there are some mines. To extract ore, you need a pickaxe and the corresponding skill (Mining).
Break off a tree branch and bind a flint stone to it using plant fibers. You can find the plant fibers and flint stone on the ground.

You need charcoal to keep the furnace hot. Saw a log into billets and put them into the kiln to fire it up. Stir up the kiln and wait until the billets have burnt up. Take the charcoal out of the kiln.

To melt down the ore, you need the corresponding skill (Smelting). Put the charcoal and ore into the furnace, fire it up and keep the temperature at 1000 degrees. Make sure that the charcoal doesn't run out! When the ore is red hot, you can pour it into the crucible.

You need a blacksmith's hammer and metal in order to forge items. You usually need the corresponding skill (Forging) to carry out blacksmith's work, but you can forge items without this in the village smithy.
Break off a tree branch and bind a flint stone to it using plant fibers. You can find the plant fibers and flint stone on the ground.

To make a shovel, break off a couple of tree branches and bind them together using plant fibers. You can find the fibers on the ground.
Or borrow a shovel from the blacksmith.
Cabbages are used in food preparation. You can plant them in plowed land (Farming).
Carrots are used in food preparation. You can plant them in plowed land (Farming).
Flax stems are used to make fabric (Procuration). You can plant flax seeds in plowed land (Farming).
Grapes are used in wine production (Cooking). You can plant them in plowed land (Farming).
Onions are used in food preparation. You can plant them in plowed land (Farming).
Potatoes are used in food preparation. You can plant them in plowed land (Farming).
Peas are used in food preparation. You can plant them in plowed land (Farming).
Wheat is used to make flour (Advanced Farming). You can plant it in plowed land (Farming). Hay is used in construction and animal lore.
Thank you, Elder. Be safe.

This is a seafarer's weapon. You can almost see raging waves in the cold gleam of the steel. This long sword ends in a sharp fang that makes its blade resemble a boarding grapnel.

A triangular eye surrounded by crude dispersing patterns is frozen on this sword's long blade. Its massive guard wrapped in straps of two-colored leather is covered by a steel bar that runs along its entire length.

The silhouette of a fish can barely be discerned in this heavy, capriciously curved blade. Despite its complex shape, it could hardly be considered elegant. Instead it is intentionally crude in the Slavard manner. Runes promising an agonizing death to all enemies have been carved into the sword.
A curved broadsword abundantly decorated with gilded tongues of flame. Khoors metalwork. The pommel is adorned with pike blades – yet another pattern typical of the steppe-dwellers.

A massive ceremonial two-handed Gottlung sword that gleams with a golden hue. The guard and pommel are also gilded. Combined with the black leather in which the handle is wrapped, this sword looks especially luxurious.

The handiwork of a Gottlung weaponsmith can be recognized at first glance – the knuckle bow shaped like a dragon's tail and the intense silhouette of the straight sword are dead giveaways. The words of a warrior's moto have been gilded and worked into the white matte steel.

The judgment for your transgression shall be deadly. In any settlement, however, you must be first judged by the laws of men, not yet the laws of the gods.
Therefore I shall bring you to the elder and tell him all, and they shall stone you with stones and hang you.
And what if... what if I make it myself?

Make an offering?
You require true understanding for that!
If you wish to offer khtynka or fresh meat, bring it hither to me. I may... speed your sacrifice on its way through the earth, to the underworld.
On your own, it shall be very hard, very hard labour indeed. The Sleeper requires the sacrifice of blood and sweet from ordinary mortals, so the scriptures say.
Should you cultivate the land or raise a building, the sweat of your brow is your sacrifice. And should you fight a battle, your offering is the blood you shed.
Asoveh dendodeh Svefnii! Talked you with our elder?
Then what do you want?

Many things are important.
Watch your breathing so that you have the strength to strike or dodge when the critical moment comes. This is called stamina. Limit your movement – do not run around, jump, or wave your weapon for no purpose. Be of a cold and calculating mind, saving your energy for when the time is right. And when that time comes, do not miss it.

Svefni's Vengeance

It's not the hammer-work, or the metal, or the intricate runes on the blade, but rather the hand of a master craftsman that holds true value. Ulfbrecht Firehand passed on many years ago, but simple swords with hilts and pommels reminiscent of the work of the revered master are still forged to this day.
The striped drawing on this blade is a tribute to an age-old tradition. Blades cooled in a block of river ice after being forged were marked like this in olden times, as they are to this day.

A Slavard sword adorned with engraved waves. It may be a simple weapon, but it's also crafted with care and bit of cleverness: the balance is displaced to the tip of the blade, and the hilt is wrapped in waterproof oiled leather. These blades are very popular among northern sailors.

The sword's hilt and pommel are topped with falcon's heads. It is a symbol, a memory that has been lost and forgotten. According to this legend, the falcon is considered to be the bird of the konungs, but not even the wise Accurs know or remember why.

This weapon is the fruit of the labor of a truly talented master craftsman. The blade's engraved fuller is lacquered and dappled with runes. The gilded symbols burn as though crying out the names of the gods.

The massive runes carved into the steel of this blade spell out a curse promising death and defeat with true northern directness. The guard and pommel are barbed and decorated with a simplistic, yet tasteful pattern.

A broad, sumptuously adorned blade made from top-notch steel. The words of the legend of the Ice Knezes are carved into the golden whorls along the fuller. How many swords like this are there in the world? You could count them on the fingers of one hand. And one of them is yours.
He will awaken in wrath and set forth for a new battle. These words shine with a golden glimmer on the burnished steel. The sword's pommel is adorned with a bloody Eye.

This heraldic banner is worn only by the best warriors who do not cover their shiny armor with tabards.
This scarlet banner with a brocade border is the essential symbol of the light cavalry that was in use in the time of the Vulpiс Empire.
Every truly battle-hardened warrior knows this symbol: the head of a unicorn on red canvas has long been the mark of heavy cavalry.

Pikemen love to show off their spears on their banners, however they are drawn. Be they artless silhouettes like arrowheads or elegant sharp-pointed complex shapes, the leaf-green background is constant.
A halberd is a serious weapon in principle, and its banner was designed to match: a sturdy bolt of emerald silk emblazoned with the image of the halberd embroidered in silver-white thread.
These light blue infantry banners are always found on the front lines. Under this standard march shieldbearers, protecting their brothers-in-arms the pikemen and archers from enemy arrows.
This piece of thick blue velvet is decorated with a simple, recognizable symbol: a full-height infantry shield.

Paint from the northern shores gives this banner a pale but fast gold hue. Once, these flags with a white axe terrified the inhabitants of the coastal villages, suddenly appearing through a thick fog accompanied by the cries of warriors and the noise of arriving ships.
The shape of a two-handed sword is stitched into this pale yellow cloth. Such banners fly high over the fray of battle, sowing fear into the hearts of those who stand against them.
The bow in this embroidered complex design is barely visible on the violet banner. Some say that this symbol, like the bow itself, was invented by Aori Goldenhanded.

This massive purple silk banner is marked with a white symbol that can be seen from afar. This mark looks like all the Slavard runes thrown together, represents the crossbow, as well as all warriors that use them.
This banner is dyed brown. It is not the most eye-catching color, but the trebuchet men do not need a bright flag. Their massive machines can be seen on the battlefield without such standards.

Harvesting Shovel of Kalle

The handle of this shovel is covered in extremely durable steel with a light, barely noticeable bluing. Like many Gottlung tools, this shovel is topped by a massive knob depicting the Eye, but the leaf-like ornament on the blade is somewhat bewildering. This is probably not symbol of Kallente, but rather a sprout of the Tree — small and slender, but gaining strength.

The rakishly curved tongues of flame are no decoration, but rather a tribute to the Khoors legend of the living flame. They say a flame once burst forth from the forge beneath the roots of the Tree. It passed through the steppe, and from its ashes were born rye, barley, and edible roots. This shovel is lucky. The nomads believe that it somehow attracts the Sparks, the few particles of living flame that still smolder in the rich black soil of the steppe.

Soft straps of tanned hide cover this thin, lacquered handle. It is topped by a strange, yet familiar symbol: Jhode's diadem and Jomfru's signs resembling sharpened knives. The iron is of high quality and clearly of Gottlung origin, but the white stripes of salt carved into the scratched steel recall the distant northern shores where this tool was forged.

Chunks of ruddy steppe soil can still be found on the broad, rounded shoulders of this shovel. The blade is riveted in thick plates of tempered iron. Half of the rivets are steel, and the other half are large, bronze, and clearly forged by another hand. This shovel must have traveled far and wide and seen many lands.

It's more of a symbol than a tool. On the metal sheets framing the head are intricate figures: humans shaped into runes. From father to son, from son to grandson, from grandson to great grandson. As long as this lineage lasts, and the spark of their descendants lives on, this magical shovel will serve them eternally.

This tool was made very carefully, but also with charmingly naive simplicity. The primitive eye and comfortable handle mark the work of a village craftsman. But of what quality! Observe the polished shoulders, easy-to-use point, and the scarlet ribbon with prayers written in an ancient dialect of Northern Götland.

A golden rod imbued with leaden heaviness. It is an allegory for power, no doubt, more than a tool. A luxurious, dangerous, heavy burden, useless in itself, but meaningful as a symbol. On the gilded ribbon, carved in ornate letters are the words: "Rule or die." Though some more pessimistic souls suggest that there is no "or" there: "Rule and die."

Knight's Crossbow
Soldier's Crossbow
Serpent's Telmir
Ceremonial Crossbow
Crossbow of the Hunt
Sunmaiden Maksha Crossbow

Most of these crossbows are nearly 100 years old. After lying idle in the army's arsenal, these crossbows arrived on boats with the survivors and have become one of the most recognizable symbols of the settlers. The handle of painted maple is decorated with the Eye of the Sleeping God and the symbol of the royal archers. Some craftsmen brand their crossbows with their symbol, but on yours, the craftsman's symbol cannot be made out.

Not all foreign weapons have a special name in Khoorsian. The steppe-dwellers respectfully call these crossbows "Amghooy tatsa" or "swift death". They may look simple, but they are reliable weapons, plus you can use the metal tail to crack nuts. Or enemies' heads.

The world telmir itself went out of use several centuries ago, but it perfectly applies to this crossbow. The metal design on the handle depicts the legendary serpent Tolki, who was fated to battle Svefnii. These crude, antique crossbows are believed to be enchanted, and that belief is strong even beyond the far northern lands.

The small, long signature carved into the handle declares the origins of this crossbow: "Made in the workshop of Hedrick vallum Wirmouth for the royal court." This exquisite weapon is one-of-a-kind: even the layers of ivory that grace its surface have an intricate unrepeating pattern forming an ornate vine, and the metal appears to represent the World Snake, the traditional decoration of the weapons of the Gottlungs.

They say that these crossbows were made by none other than Orgend, one of the last artisan giants who lived in the old world. It is believed that he could speak Common, as well as read and write, and all his weapons were decorated with the shapes of animals. Of course, that could be something a merchant made up to raise the price. Who would know?

An unknown master created this crossbow out of the wood of an ash tree. And image of Jhode would be fitting on the handle of that thing which brings death, but the creator thought otherwise, and as if to laugh in the face of fear, decorated the weapon with flowers and a golden vine.

Flaming Falchion
Serpent's Malchus
Harvester

In the channels carved along the handle of this axe are golden patterns in which everyone sees what they want to see. One might see Holza's thread, another might glimpse the Eye, and, if they want to badly enough, another just might see Northern runes.

A treasured weapon among rich mercenaries who usually buy it not for battle, but for bragging rights. All of these axes are believed to be copies of the beloved weapon of Roderic the Gray, the famous woodland bandit.

The groove on the blade takes on a certain significance if you hold the weapon handle-down: you can see a depiction of a dungeon beneath the roots of the Tree and a massive Spark at its center – the allegory of the greatest of weapons. The Slavards are always glad to point out that the symbol is carved not into a sword, but an axe, just as it is told in the Northern legends.

The tale of the wild Gavran has come down to us from olden times: there was once a gang of seamen who sowed terror among merchant ships and port cities. For twenty years they pillaged without getting caught. They say that their weapons – even their axes – were ornately decorated, and they still pop up in weapon shops from time to time.

The most valuable part of this sword is not the black blade made of hard Gottlung steel or the tongues of golden flame, but the silver-coated guard depicting a wrathful smith-god with a smoldering visage. This adornment is much more ancient than the sword itself. The inscription on the brand says "He who from the verge of oblivion hails."

The gilded engraving contains Slavard motifs and brief inscriptions in the Gottlung tongue. This coarse, yet beautiful sword is clearly the work of a Northern master craftsman. The serpent on the pommel is Tolki, and the ruby in his jaws represents the Spark of the Hammerer.

An ancient and rare item of dwindling supply. It is a ritual weapon of a vanished cult of assassins who once worshiped Johde. It could be a fake, but its authenticity is quite simple to verify: if the falchion is real, then any blood that empurples the blade will flow along the runnels and into the goddess's sickle, turning it crimson.

Craftsman's Pickax

First-rate tempered steel is hardly this tool's crowning glory. Anyone who picks it up is sure to notice the strange color of the bright-purple straps. Some say that the people of the north extract the dye from terrible white sea creatures that get caught in their nets.

The Khoors have few truly useful tools, but this is one of them. The head of this pickax is not simply forged, it's cut from a thick tempered rod, decorated with intricate carvings and gilding. The thick handle of the tool it woven from top to bottom in soft leather straps.

Once there was an imperial province with a workshop where people from across the land traveled to get their tools. These pickaxes have maintained their value: The shining, untarnished gilding, the comfortable handles, and plush leather. Also, each pickax is decorated with a carved figure of a god.

For a northerner, a pickax like this is much more than a mere tool. It is a holy relic passed from father to son. Its wooden handle is covered in patterns and runes, and the older the pickax, and the longer the family's history, the more runes and symbols adorn it.

The secret of this alloy is now hidden in distant mountains across the ocean. The pale metal does not rust. It cools and heats gradually, and it is light enough to make an entire tool out of it, handle and all.

This tool may seem hastily made, but it was constructed with great knowledge. Instead of gilding, it has copper plating, and instead of decorations, it is topped by a small steel pick. The handle is encompassed by simple straps of boiled leather.
Excommunicated
General's Standard

The sunlight playing on the simple pattern of gold thread gives life to the sparks, and the details shimmer when the wind blows. This proud, shining banner is imbued with a special strength: hundred, thousands of people are willing to follow it into the furious flames of battle...
Archimancurus' Old Garb

Time has not been kind to this scarlet mantle, but a gentle, noble shimmer remains unaltered. It bears a barely noticeable pattern, decorated with leaves, roots, and sparks in its iridescent sheen. The fabric is of Khoorsian origin, but it is not often to be found even in the largest markets of Kaskir-Unon. It was obviously custom made.
Ancient Makthrid Costume

This old mantle seems almost velveteen to the touch: many years have passed, but the fabric, shipped from the southern coast, has not been worn through. The garment is tailored to the owner's exact figure and is sewn in thousands of large, reliable stitches made by the diligent hands of apprentices.

Sickle of Abundant Reaping

No, that isn't gold: It's a simple pattern that seems to shine, never dimming or wearing away as time goes by. Those inclined to believe in superstitions swear the blade of this sickle rings quietly when ripe wheat is near. The handle smells faintly of grass. Whether it soaked in the aroma in the fields or the scent is the remained of a magic potion inside, no one can say.
Sun Sickle

An ancient, special thing. This sickle is the work of a less than gifted smith, but it is not crude. Steel with an admixture of copper came out light, flexible, and strong. The gold spots on the blade create a strange pattern that can be contemplated for hours. It is said that sometimes face of Amate can be seen in these spots. Who knows?
Bandit's Bardiche

The Slavard runes etched in the blade form a simple prayers—asking the gods to accept this bloody sacrifice. In exchange, the bearer of the weapon asks for a small boon: protection from the noose, the gallows, and any other shameful death. The handle of the bardiche ends with something remotely similar to a pike pole. It seems that once this weapon served a marauder plundering the coast.
Intricate Halberd

The hard steel of the blade is difficult to sharpen, but once sharpened, it stays that way for a long time. The head itself was forged in the days of the royal court; it acquired its proud, gilded ornaments much later, just like its sanded oaken handle, protected with flaxseed oil. How many craftsmen labored over this incredible weapon?
Igelsbronn

These spears have a dubious honor. They say they smell distinctly of blood, even years after their last use in battle. Legend has it that sometimes in the dark of the night, needles on these spears come to life with sparks, the souls of the fallen warriors searching endlessly for His forge.
Twintail

It is tempting to think that this clever spear was born of some kind of joke, but the gray-haired half-blind elders recall Ordun the Marten and his band who was famous for their endless resourcefulness and creativity. Triangular helms with two layers of aventail, shields covered by ductile leather and these very spears have outlived their original bearers and even the memory of them.
Imperial Lance

Is that steel? Or silver? Not every smith can tell, and only a rare few can recall this celestial metal which is occasionally discovered in remote lands. The spear itself impresses with its simplicity and at the same time, the minute details of its construction. If you look carefully, you're bound to find a subtle signature in the shape of a crown. What does it mean? Opinions vary.
Cavalry Master's Spear

Finding a weapon like this one is a great stroke of luck. Very few were ever made. One for each of the cavalry commanders who served in the army of the Vulpian Empire. It seems as though time has not touched this weapon. The blued steel flashes with a dry shine and the gilding looks fresh. Though the Empire and the cavalry masters are no more, the spears remain. And will remain for ages to come.
Aorienknecht

The sheen of gold that covered this lance can drive a man to distraction, but the spear is not for parades. It's heavy, hard blade was indeed intended for battle and honed to the sharpness of a razor. The craftsman's stamp is nowhere to be seen, but nevertheless, it's clear this is one of a kind.
Goldflower

A fine halberd with a dubious honor. No one makes such arms anymore, so know, if you come across this in a store, it is either a very good fake or looted from a grave, torn from the bony grip of a dead guard who served the highest echelons of the fallen Empire.
Runic Halberd

The blade is adorned with a runic poem and is much older than the other parts of the weapon. This halberd was cobbled together from many parts, from the traditions and materials of the lands of the Empire. Here there is red gold from the Khoorish steppe and there mottled northern steel, and it is covered in rhombuses and rivers that mark it unequivocally as a Gottlung weapon.
Gavran of the Dead

This weapon is from a time and place where marauding was no shame. The bardiche looks like a war axe without a brand, but everyone knows that it was forged by Hodrick the Feeble, one of the greatest smiths of the North. It was one of the last he forged. Among the dead soldiers depicted on the side of the Gavran, a young face can be seen. It is Hodrick's son who died in battle.

Landsknechtsschwert

The silhouette of this sword is ideal for crests: There isn't a stronger or more recognizable weapon in all the world. This shape has been repeated by many craftsmen, but this blade was made with special love and care. The symbol on crossguard though now partially worn away still reads "Manfred" to those who look closely.
Tolkischwert

The overstated grace of this claymore is deceptive: It's not just a toy for jesters at the fair to chop up pumpkins while blindfolded to the roar of the crowd. The weapon is large, but perfectly balanced. This sword comes from the distant shores of the old world. The leather braiding on the hilt has not lost its color over the years: a sign that the weapon has been taken care of.
Schwarzenblod

An unremarkable claymore which will attract the gaze of any connoisseur. The pattern is etched into it in a special way. A weapon like that could only have been forged in one place: in the remote, swampy regions of the southeast of the fallen empire. The steel blade sharpens poorly, but it is almost eternal and retains its sharpness once earned.
Lord of the North

The runes on the blade of this sword have been reforged many times. The explanation for this lies in the Slavard traditions: A claymore like this is nothing more than a gift from a jarl to his eldest son. If the elder perished, the sword was passed on to the next. And the dedication, emblazoned on the blade, had to be changed accordingly.
Great Claymore

This sword bears silent witness to a great plague, and is a mournful reminder of the world we left behind across the great water... Once, such swords were used by the imperial cavalry when they had to battle on foot.
Gold-headed Lance
A weapon whose rich luxury obscures what is most important. The head of the spear is carved of elm. Long-lived and light, it was soaked in a special solution which gives it the fastness of stone.
Dark Hand

An experienced warrior will see right through the deceptive simplicity of this spear. The vamplate that protects the bearer's hand was forged with great care and delicacy. The whole weapon, from tip to end is composed of many small layers of burnished steel. And each layer bears the mark of the forges of the capital...
Guardian

The artisan who created this spear no doubt competed in tournaments himself: the attention to detail would be unusual for a craftsman unfamiliar with the sport. Even the gilded engraving is slightly recessed into the polished steel, to prevent it from fading, no doubt.
Blintzenspier

A copy of the legendary jousting lance that once belonged to Roderic Affelheim, a knight who was very close to the Sovereign. Weapons like this are the result of many master craftsmen's toil, trying whatever materials they could in a desperate attempt to achieve the perfect strength and balance the original lance had. Whether or not any can be considered a success is unknown.
Sentry

Every weapon shop of the old empire was overstuffed with bows like these, but only a rare few were made as well as this one. This bow, braided with two different kinds of leather, has enough power to pierce an enemy wearing light armor.
Falconer

Even in the best of times, only two hundred of these bows could be made. Their delicate, stamped silver detailing point to their Khoorish origins, but the style of the bow is typical of Gottlung design: requiring strength to draw, but shooting long distances.
Aoru Utzgoul

What makes this weapon remarkable is not its fine finishing. These mighty bows are not made, but grown. Their tale begins with a pale white willow branch at a bend of the river, chanted over by a shaman of the steppe. In its fourth year, it is cut and bathed in the smoke of desert grass, and enveloped in gold.
Widowed Bow

This northern bow may seem crude and overlarge. What's more, rumors say that all these bows are cursed, and their owners, knowingly or not, serve the Ice-Eyed Johde. The bowstring is woven from the hair of a widow. Supposedly, the hair is the source of the bow's magical power.
Baron's Bow

The limbs of this bow rival yew in springiness, but the wood itself is light and dense, with a nearly imperceptible pink tint. Its origins are hard to pin down. The ornate embellishments of this weapon are not gilded steel, but pure gold.
The Art of War!

Blitzenberg

The blade of this sword is forged straight and later sharpened in the Flamberge manner. Such difficult work is justified, as this blade outmatches even tempered blades in strength. Its form is simple and minimal: in it, one can sense the hand of a master craftsman.
Svargralf

This sword's name is an ancient Slavard word that indicates the claw of either a bear or a wolf. The blade is fully worthy of this name: crude, simple, savage, and a little rusted, but surprisingly deadly.
Ulcer

The dark cherry lacquer on the blade may be reminiscent of a flame, but rumor has given this sword a different name. The caustic nickname Ulcer, given by mercenaries, comes from its ability to leave gaping wounds that do not heal.
Count's Flamberge

The gilt on this sword is applied in a special way: it doesn't tarnish with time, there are almost no scratches on it, and the inscription on the hilt glimmers like a diamond. The blacksmith's brand, stamped in an inconspicuous place, is death's head with its eyes rolled back. Whose brand is it? No one knows.
You're about to build a spawning point inside of your town claim. Remember, outlanders don't have the rights to be here! Are you sure?
Green Villeinese Tunic
Boar's Tooth
You're about to build a spawning point inside of your town claim. Remember, outlanders don't have the rights to be here! Are you sure?
Terskelglaff
Formal Cavalry Glaive
A long green tunic covered by a well-made knee-length cloak. Beneath the thick flax is a quilted lining of soft leather. Thick golden trim twists around it, adorning the cloak's tails and sleeves.
This glaive's rough handle has been dried almost to the point of turning white. A carelessly-made blade covered in rough, straight teeth has been attached to the thickened part.

The intricately forged tip is hollow, and a steel ring slips back and forth across it, making the blade heavier when it strikes. "Turneskangen" is carved into the glaive, signifying that this is the weapon of a warrior-priest sworn to protect the tower of the same name.

Polished to a sheen, the steel blade is adorned with a flat, gilded bas-relief depicting Terskel holding a horn. The handle is no less sumptuous - it is covered in strips of black leather and trimmed in gold.

It is unusual to find a glaive with a two-sided blade. However, the abundance of tiny, fine details clearly indicates this weapon's intended purpose: it is part of the formal gear of the elite black cavalry.
